item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Hey, I am Christos, a marketing and analytics expert working in tech. I've worked for Facebook, TikTok and other tech companies.

Interested to know more about my work? Check out my portfolio.

You can find me on LinkedIn, Twitter, see examples of my projects on Github, or email me at christos@visvardis.com

item.title: Google Ads PerformanceElements [draft]
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
TL/DR: I analyzed this year's data for our Google Ads to see which campaign components, such as audiences, demographics, keywords, and secondary metrics like ad strength and keyword quality, can be used to optimize our main KPIs (CPA, CVR, CTR).

Based on the recent Growth Analytics Framework I posted, I wanted to dig into some of our Google Ads Campaign elements that affect campaigns performance. As noted in the framework above, the goal is to have some rough guidelines and pre-flight checks that can be used to optimize campaign performance.

Obviously, this is an iterative process: the more data we get and the more tests we run the better this type of analysis will be. Also, keep in mind this analysis is not based on incrementality-based tests data, but on reporting data from Google ads (with the attribution logic used on the platform).

For this analysis, Ive used Google Ads data from the start of the year, so it covers roughly a 6 month-period since January 1st, 2021.

The analysis covers the below elements and secondary metrics that we can monitor to improve Google Ads performance:

  • Ad Strength
  • Keyword Quality Score
  • Asset Performance
  • Asset Type
  • Ad Type
  • Audiences
  • Age and Gender
  • Day of the Week
  • Keyword March Types

All of the above have been added to the Google Ads Dashboard Ive created so that one can easily monitor primary and secondary metrics with breakdowns by country, campaign etc.

Ad Strength

Ad Strength is an indicative score that shows the effectiveness of an ad. Ad Strength is not meant to replace our main KPIs (CPA, Conversion Rate), but rather complement them and help us in the ad creation process.

As mentioned above, Ad Strength does not necessarily guarantee a better performance. For example, you can see that in our case Average, Good and Excellent performed within a similar range for our main KPIs. What is more Average Strength had a lower CPA than Good and Excellent, for example.

Thats not to say that we should be aiming for a non-Excellent score of our ads, but rather that we should be focusing on our KPIs to judge our campaigns performance, and using Ad Strength as a tool to improve elements of our ads.

In this case, we should be avoiding a Poor rating, which applied to 18% of our total spend for the first half of 2021, and in general aim for an above-average score.

When creating an ad Google Ads will give recommendations on the elements that can be improved and an indication of the Ad Strength for that ad.

This way we can aim for an average or above Ad Strength and reassess our performance based on Ad Strength. The goal of secondary metrics like Ad Strength is to be used so that we can improve our primary KPIs.

Keyword Quality Score

Quality Score is a metric available at the keyword level and is an indication of how relevant an and a landing page is to the users searching for our keywords.

70% of our spend gets a score of 8-10, whereas 30% of the spend is applied on keywords with score of 7 or less.

There is a considerable decline in performance when Keyword Quality gets a score of 7 or less, so Keyword Quality Score is a good proxy metric to have as a goal to improve, and also to monitor when running our campaigns.

The individual components that influence Quality Score are Expected Click-through-rate, Ad Relevance, and Landing Page Experience, whose scores can be found in Google Ads at a keyword level, marked as average, below average, or above average.

One way to improve this is see which keywords are below average in some of those categories and update our ad text, keyword selection, or landing page content accordingly.

Google Ads Keywords with below average quality components

Quality Score is a diagnostic tool and should be used as such. Its not the end goal, but a means to an end, similar to Ad Strength.

Google recommends looking at the 3 components separately and trying to improve them for a better user experience (see Googles recommendations and tips for each component).

Asset Performance

Elements such as the headlines and description of a Google Ad constitute its assets. Google Ads provides us with a performance rating for our assets as seen in the table below.

Ourgoal is to avoid a low ratingwhich as seen below correlates with a really high CPA. So far weve been doing a very good job keeping our rating high and this secondary metric can serve a monitoring function for the quality of our assets, similar to the quality scores mentioned in the previous section.

Asset Type and Ad Type

We can also look into the different Asset Types and Ad Types and their respective performances, when people click on those elements or ads.

In terms of assets, headlines and descriptions are the main elements of search ads. The question here is whether we should useimages/logos where applicable. As seen in the table below they rarely perform well.Most of theclickshappen on the traditional headline/description elements which perform much better.

Regarding ad types, Responsive search ads and Expanded Text ads are the best performers and roughly 99% of our total spend goes to those two ad types.

Audiences

Targeting and audiences is one of the ways that we can improve our campaigns, so we can see below if there are opportunities to spend more on under-utilized audiences. For example,Extended Demographic could be an audience where we could scale our spendand get a good performance, although the data is limited so far.

As part of theGoogle Ads DashboardIve included a tab on audiences where you can find more granular data on different audiences as seen below.

As mentioned with the other campaign elements, this should be used as an imperfect guide of how to improve our targeting and relevance. Just because an audience performs better than other it doesnt mean we should exclude all other audience, but we should use it as a guide to reallocate our budget towards better performing audiences.

You can see more about audience types on Google Ads help.

Moreover, we can see our demographic performance data below.

The 18-24 and >45 groups seem to be more expensive than 25-44 in terms of CPA. However, the current allocation is sensible based on the fact that there are no extreme outliers in terms of performance. Focusing on our ad and keyword quality makes more sense than trying to pick audiences based on demographics.

Day of the Week

Could the day of the week influence our ad performance? A weekly business cycle does exist as seen in thechart below, where weekends tend to have fewer signups and conversions than week days, with Wednesday usually being the peak day of each week.

Conversions and Signups for WP.com by day

That doesnt mean that we should disregard days with lower volume, but we can also monitor their performance in terms of our main KPIs (CPA,CVR,CTR).

Google Ads performance by day of the week

As seen in the table above, our Google Ad spend is lower on weekends (when we usually see a lower volume), but the CPA and CVR rate on those days tends to be better than weekdays. There could be untapped opportunities where we can test what happens when increasing our spend on weekends. Does the lower overall volume mean that well start getting diminishing returns, or is there room for our spend to grow on weekends and take advantage of the lower CPAs?

In the Google Ads dashboard Ive also included a Time of day table, which makes sense to monitor on a country (or region) basis, in order to see what the best-performing times for a given timezone are.

Keywords and Match Types

There are 3 keyword match types (broad, phrase, and exact) as explained by the below example fromGoogle.

Usually, tighter matching will result to a better performance, and in our case we have a high spend on Exact matching. A a user can search for our keywords without having to type long phrases or descriptions. Even 1-2 word search queries such as blog, wordpress, website builder are enough for user to find what theyre looking for.

Since keywords are an important part of campaigns, it makes sense to look at keywords at a campaign or ad level. Ive added Campaign, Ads and Keywords tabs in the Google Ads Dashboard where you can see the match rates for both Campaign Keywords and the actual Search Queries performed by users.

We can edit match type for our campaigns based on the performance seen above, and also exclude keywords adding them to the negative keywords list, if theyre not relevant.

item.title: Aha Moment [draft]
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
@pbonahora recently started a discussion on what could be WordPress.coms Aha moment, similar to Facebooks famous 7 friends in 10 days. @kr213 has already done significant work on this, and @pbonahora and I had discussions with him on the work that has been done and how we can use it for improving WP.coms KPIs.

Goal: The goal of this post is to provide an overview of the relevant work that has been done for WordPress.com's aha moment/activation metric and to suggest potential next steps for a WP.com project aligned with WP.com's goals. 

What is an aha moment?

An aha moment or an activation metric. It is a quantifiable way of understanding which user actions/events lead to increased propensity for a user to become active and thus stay on the platform. An aha metric will help us understand how to unlock growth.

For Facebook, that was the catchy 7 friends in 10 days which would lead to a user becoming a long-term user for Facebook. This was then broken down into any product features that could help reach that activation metric (e.g. feature friends posts on newsfeed more prominently).

Relevant work so far

@kr213 has already done an amazing job looking into different metrics that could increase user retention.

Two main features stood out in this analysis: traffic to the users site, and users making edits to their pages.

  • Traffic: 55 visits in 10 days following site launch  a user that hits this activation metric could increase their chance of retention by ~30% (60% vs. 45%).
  • Edits: Users make 10 edits to their pages/posts within 14 days of site creation  a user that hits this activation could increase their chance of retention by ~25% (60% vs. 48%) . (Edits were chosen over number of pages, because there is a wide spectrum of site sizes, e.g. 1-page sites vs sites with e-com sites with multiple product pages).

As a follow-up to this Site Launch Rate has been added as a proxy metric for activation, which is also monitored as part of Forge Health.

Which events could lead to an increase of activation metrics?

  • Traffic: Once again @kr213 has suggested events that could potentially lead in increased traffic and is working on a model to predict traffic for these events.

As part of our discussion we can brainstorm hypotheses on what could lead to improved Site Launch Rates and increased number of Edits.

Success

@kr213 s work looks at at paid users, and defines a successful user as a user that renews after 1 year. We can discuss if wed like to include other goals to reflect the Top 3 Marketing Objectives.

A very useful framework that @kr213 has proposed to look at the overall process is the following:

  • What features/navigation improvements/steps can we take to encourage users to launch their site?
  • Users launch sites (necessary step for users to make site public and start gaining traffic).
  • What features/incentives can we provide users to increase traffic?
  • Help users increase traffic (as its the biggest indicator of improving retention).
  • Better retention!

Next Steps

  • Discuss and define our activation metric. Moreover, we should assess its feasibility. For example, traffic might be a better goal for a user than just launching a site. However, how directly can we influence traffic as opposed to increasing the odds that a user will launch their site?
  • @kr213 is working on a Site Launch Prediction project, which can help us in the above questions.
  • @pbonahora has suggested a combination of quantitative (the analyses mentioned above) and qualitative (e.g. focus groups to help us form hypotheses) approach. Lets discuss what the best approach is.

Comments

One thing that has been pretty consistent across all projects Ive worked on, where users create anything, has been that usage, advocacy, and retention all go up once the user has shared their work publicly. We could look at some sort of tracking to see how often their url is shared across open services like Facebook/Twitter.

I would also really recommend our post-launch email/notification campaigns include some basic best-practices and onboarding like:

  • Share your post
  • Add your site url to your social media profiles
  • Create a new post with a different type of content in it e.g. audio, video, or other embeds
  • Activate social sharing to make sure others can share your content too
  • Set up a basic email list and start collecting your readers emails, etc.

Theres just a certain level of accountability and commitment that builds up when you know other people are actually aware of what youre doing. All of these things link back to traffic to their site but if we go this route we can also set a good foundation for getting more granular in the future and looking at things like transactions for ecommerce plans or subscribers for blogs/podcasts.

After reading the previous discussions and this post, it almost feels like were converging to these two metrics. Itd be great to finalize those. On the traffic side, I think theres actually a lot we can do to help our customers. If we decide site traffic is our aha moment, launching a site will just be a means to an end such that itll be your first step to get more traffic.

On top of the recommendations listed above, Id like to add a few more ideas to help customers reach these goals:

  • Guest posting: This is really important especially for any blog type sites to gather traffic. Customers can tap into the niche segment theyre working on. We as WordPress.com can actually help form a guess posting community. @thatmikebal also pinging you as this might be part of our community growth.
  • Social media marketing: We can make it even easier for customers to share with predefs and content pre-populated such as header image etc to increase traffic from their own circle. We dont highlight this enough in the product after someone publishes. Example below is after Ive published a post. We can introduce elements here to share in as many social media accounts as possible.
  • Education: We can help customers and educate them on keyword selection, how to analyze site traffic, creating content etc. Were experts after all in these fields

Good timing on this post! Well very likely have a pod focused on this starting in August.

Im looking forward to this becoming a pod focus as theres so much work we could do to achieve these aha moments.

  • Share from you personal profile Facebook
  • Share in any relevant groups following their guidelines and rules for posting Facebook
  • Share on Twitter leveraging relevant hashtags Pro Tip: write 3-5 different versions so you can share several times over the next week.
  • If youre using a link tree service for instagram, share to Instagram with either your featured image or a modified more engaging image your audience will stop to look at.
  • Let any sites you referenced in your post know what youre sharing and recommending their content. Provide them with some prewritten social posts so its easy for them to promote yours.
  • Post your new post in the WordPress.com blogging channel and the channel specific to your topic (doesnt exist yet)
  • Submit your content for our weekly roundup of featured customers via this form (doesnt exist yet)

  • Revamping a Discovery destination (Discover and Reader among others in the past)
  • Sharing successfully launched sites from your cohort (imagine First Month onboarding emails that listed 10 other sites that launched the same month as yours!)
  • Seamless CRM Using MailPoet to better communicate with your existing and new contacts
  • SEO tools and courses

item.title: Marketing Systems Project: Problem Approach [draft]
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Hi everyoneexcited to share my first p2 post!

I wanted to give everyone more visibility about what we are trying to solve with the Marketing Systems Exploration, Audit, and Design Project and why its important for the business.

Why We Care

Accurate Marketing data is the lifeblood of any effective data-driven acquisition team. 

 We need it to:

  • Measure effectiveness of every dollar spent (ROI, ROAS, LTV/CAC,etc)
  • Determine the best decisions for the next best dollar we spend (marginal return, incremental return)
  • Directly attribute channel performance to key business metrics
  • Show us blindspots in our performance metrics
  • Define our marketing and business roadmaps
  • etc

The goal of this project is to enable teams to make decisions and take the best actions for the business.

What It Is

Marketing Systems is a broad name that is really the compilation of many different components across a number of teams including:

  1. Marketing Platforms (Google, FB,etc)
  2. Marketing Tracking (Pixels, Tags, Triggers)
  3. ETL into our data warehouse (Fivetran) 
  4. Raw Marketing Data Tables (fivetran.doubleclick_campaign_manager,etc)
  5. Internal Data Tables (Billing, Tracks,etc) 
  6. Aggregated Data Tables (Acquisition Explore, FRP)
  7. Data Visualization (Looker Dashboards)

All of these core elements work together to provide us a holistic view of the performance of our acquisition channels. 

With so many components in this marketing data funnel, it can be easy to solve for our blindspots if we focus on the wrong part. This can lead to unintended team thrash, building technical debt to our existing stack, and creating unscalable architecture for future challenges.

What We Will Solve

At a high level, we are planning to solve:

  • Data Accuracy (Data is not accurate in YYY source)
  • Data Availability (We dont have the ability to see YYY in our current dashboards)
  • Data Definition (We dont know what this YYY field means)
  • Data Usability (I have to use X looker views to merge with my channel UI data)

Our goal should be to build a solid foundation that not only systematically solves for each of the current blind spots but also will allow us to scale into more sophisticated types of analyses/models like attribution.

How We Will Get There

Because there are so many distinct components to this tactic, we will be tackling this in a few key phases:

Phase 1: Understand and Identify Blind Spots for our acquisition team

Phase 2: Understand and Identify opportunities with each of these components 

Phase 3: Partner with Data and Martech teams to build a roadmap of deliverables

Phase 4:Rebuild core sources of reporting and truth for the Acquisition program as a whole

Phase 5:Rebuild Channel level dashboards based on individual channel level needs/feedback

Phase 6: Deploy Attribution Plan

Phase 7: Implement Logic into core tables and dashboarding

item.title: Marketing Analytics Dos and Donts
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Anyone who works in marketing knows that analytics is a prerequisite for their job. 

You probably start your day by: 

  1. looking at performance dashboards
  2. reporting the important numbers to your boss 
  3. making decisions based on what the analytics indicate 

Or at least thats what most marketers preach.

Lets review the Dos and Donts of marketing analytics so that you can make the most of your data. 

1. DONT: Mess up tracking 

It all begins with gathering all the data, and gathering it correctly. 

In order to do that, you need to make sure youve implemented all the different tracking codes for the various tools and marketing channels you are using. 

These include tracking codes for your analytics tools such asGoogle Analyticsor Adobe Analytics, or third-party cookies, pixels and codes for the marketing platforms and channels you use, e.g. the Facebook pixel for your Facebook ads or the Criteo One Tag.

Usually, it is convenient to use a tag container likeGoogle Tag Managerwhich - as the word container implies - is a platform where you can implement all your tags in one place.

A tracking code is usually a short javascript snippet that you place into your website. 

However, youd also want to implement events for specific actions that people take on your website, e.g. add to cart, purchase, add payment details, sign up etc.

***Keep in mind that if you have a website and an app youll need separate tracking implementations for each one. Moreover, iOS and Android will have different tracking codes that you need to insert into your app.

Allmajor analytics toolsand marketing platforms have their own documentation on how to place their tracking codes on your website and app.

Make sure to implement the tags and events as instructed by the documentation, otherwise your tags might be sending the wrong events, or not firing at all. The consequence is that you might not be getting any data, or receiving the wrong data which means that all your reporting will be off!

2. DO: Test and verify that your tags are tracking properly

After you implement all your tags its crucial to make sure that they actually fire correctly. 

Most analytics tools and tag managers have a live or testing view so that you can check your tags and events in real time.

A good tip is to act as a real user by following the typical journey that they would take and see if youre capturing all the events on the right pages.

Moreover, make sure to use different devices, browsers and operating systems (desktop, tablet, both iOS and Android for mobile) as they might have different implementations or technical requirements.

Also, cross-check your different analytics tools and sources for discrepancies when it comes to the same event or metric. A variance up to 10-15% is acceptable as different analytics tools might have a different definition for a metric that can be found on other tools, or tags might fire differently across platforms.

3. DO: Integrate your different marketing sources

Its easy to get lost into all the different reporting tools and marketing channels that you are using. 

Your company and the C-level executives will want to have one point of reference for reporting, so its essential that you integrate all your different data sources.

For this, you might need an ETL tooland likely a data warehouse like Google BigQuery or Amazon Redshift.

An ETL toolcan help you connect all your marketing data into a single source of truth without having to spend time and valuable engineering resources to create pipelines that might or might not work properly.

4. DONT:  Waste time on vanity metrics, choose the right KPIs

With all the metrics and dimensions in your database you might be tempted to track every little thing that is available to you.

However, dont go down the rabbit hole of vanity metrics that dont really matter to your business. 

For example, no matter how interesting it is to see how many people liked your Facebook posts (which is a metric available to you via the Facebook Marketing API), if it doesnt assist or correlate your business goals like sales or leads, there is no point in creating marketing reports for such metrics.

Focus on the KPIs that align with your business goals. In most cases, those should be ROI, revenue, sales, Customer Lifetime Value, Leads etc. 

You can of course track secondary metrics or micro-conversions as well, as long as they represent meaningful actions that users carry out on your website or app, e.g. reading your blog posts, how much time they spend on your website, adding something to cart but not buying etc.

5. DO: Create relevant reports and dashboards for different stakeholders

After gathering all your data in one place through an ETL you should start building dashboards for the stakeholders in your organization.

Remember that every department is interested in different metrics and levels of data granularity. 

Areport / dashboardfor the CEO or CFO should be limited to the big picture; KPIs such as ROI, revenue, active users are the things they will be mainly interested in.

A CMO might want to see the performance of each marketing channel, whereas performance marketing managers will want to dig deeper and check the performance of each individual campaign.

The best way to find out what your colleagues need in a dashboard is talk to them and ask them questions about their business goals and what is important to them on a daily basis. 

Find what metrics better represent the goals that they have and incorporate them into the dashboard. 

Your dashboards will not be perfect the first time you create them. Keep getting feedback from the various stakeholders and improve them accordingly.

6. DONT: Build overwhelming/confusing reports. Use your reports to ask business questions and produce actionable insights

Dashboards are usually more useful when they dont overwhelm the user with a myriad of metrics and numbers.

Instead, they should point out trends and data points that can be used as insights to help decision-making.

Instead of trying to just depict a metric that you think is useful, try to answer a business question with the right data. For example, you could try and find information on questions like Who are my most valuable customers? or Which marketing channels are the most effective for acquiring leads?. 

Questions like these will guide you on what charts and reports to create, but they will also help the user make decisions based on your business data. 

If, for example, your reports show that your most valuable customers are people aged 25-35 who read your blog posts about new electronic gadgets, you could create more content like that and also promote similar products.

Or, if you find out that Facebook and Snapchat generate quality leads with a lower cost compared to other channels, you could shift your marketing budget and effort toward social media to improve your overall performance.

7. DO: Focus on attribution

One of the biggest challenges that marketers face is that the customer journey has become more convoluted due to the presence of multiple touchpoints and the fact that every marketing channel will report numbers differently.

Thus, it becomes increasingly difficult for companies to know how to spend their budget effectively and have visibility on the true performance of each channel.

All marketing channels will have a bias in favor of their own data and will tend to attribute all conversions to their platform regardless of how many other channels were present in the customer journey.

By gathering all your data from various marketing channels into one place you can oversee the performance of all marketing activities in a more holistic way.

Since you can connect the touchpoints (all clicks, impressions, ad spend, sales revenue) from Search, Social Media, Newsletter, Affiliates in a unified way, you can create or use pre-existingattribution modelsto weigh the contribution of each channel to your business results.

By doing this, youll be able to make better decisions when it comes to how to allocate your budget and youll save money by reducing the spend on channels that underperform.

8. DO: Make analytics part of your company culture

In order to make the most out of the above points, your company needs to embracemarketing analyticsas part of its mindset.

Decisions should be data-driven and analytics should be in the core of your marketing team.

Companies that neglect data and analytics do it at their own peril.

Those who utilize data-driven principles will be able to take advantage of marketing channels in a much more efficient way, without wasting dollars on activities that can't prove their value.

item.title: How to measure Lifetime Value: a comprehensive guide for marketers and data analysts
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
What isnt measured isnt improved. What this means for you is that if you want to really grow your business or grow your game you need to be measuring the factors that will drive that growth.

I want to drill into the specifics of how a lot of you are doing this today and provide some tips to bring that to the next level.

How can measurement drive real business growth?

I've identified three components that can help lead to success and growth:

1) Plan for people first: Start with a clear objective and use people-based data as the underlying foundation of all your campaign decisions from setting your bid strategy to running a measurement study to optimizing based on insights you learn. Shift away from proxy metrics like last-click to more valuable methods like multi-touch attribution, all based on people.

2) Focus on learning: Get comfortable testing different ad formats, creative executions and bidding strategies to really learn what works well and what doesnt. Then take those learnings and act on them agilely, with confidence.

3) Compare across everything (as much as you can). Never act or measure in a silo, and dont think about measurement as something that should be done at a single moment in time. Think about your campaigns holistically from start to finish, objective to outcome and across platforms, channels and publishers. 

From quantity to quality: The evolution of performance metrics

True business growth comes from measuring what matters and focusing on outcomes that are important to your business. I have seen performance metrics evolve over time as a result from those that purely focused on traffic to more sophisticated proxies for success such as cost of traffic/conversion and even return on ad spend. 

Ultimately what you should care most about is having an accurate view of the full revenue the user will deliver over their lifetime so that we can assess the value of an acquisition channel and the cost you are willing to pay.

What is Lifetime Value?

Lifetime Value is the total monetary value delivered by the user over their lifetime in a service (e.g. an app or a game). It basically is the predicted revenue and cost incurred after acquiring a new customer. 

And whether you're a retailer, eCommerce or gaming company - it's more important than ever to acquire the best customers who will help drive long term value and growth for your business.

Focusing on clicks, installs and acquisitions is important in a growth phase, but for most businesses to deliver long term profit and sustain growth, a focus on lifetime value for your marketing strategies can help deliver long term impact.

Marketing leaders today do more than acknowledge that customer lifetime value matters they actually focus their spending and staff resources accordingly.

A Bain & Company survey of roughly 500 companies found that marketing leaders exhibit a few characteristics that set them apart from the bottom 25% of companies. The leaders are:

  • 3.5 times more likely to embed employees in marketing who specifically focus on understanding the customer's end to end experience;
  • 1.9 times more likely to scrutinize customer lifetime value in addition to more traditional last-touch metrics such as ROI, customer acquisition cost and click-through rate

Moreover, in the 2018 Internet Trends Report by Mary Meeker, the importance of Lifetime Value was specifically called out an increasingly important metric marketers are starting to focus on as acquisition costs continue to skyrocket.

So how can marketers being to tackle the future today?

For advertisers looking to drive action conversions are important to driving volume, but does that always translate into value? From our studies were seeing a clear discrepancy between conversions and value. 

In a study conducted by my team at Facebook (Marketing Science), we looked at a set of people who converted on a mobile-app install ad and if they turned into paying customers of the service.

And we found that if somebody is going to start using the app, their first paid action will probably occur within 7 days of install. he majority of installs do not result in a revenue-producing event within 28 days.

Putting this into perspective, concentrating on getting the lowest cost per install is not going to make you more money over time if youre just picking up lots of people who wont use your app.

In another report that we did in collaboration with AppsFlyer, we found out that 3.8% of Mobile Gaming users end up becoming payers eventually.

Shifting campaign strategy from volume to value

As opposed to traditional CPA, and calculated ROAS, this predictive approach to LTV can help marketers better optimize for lifetime ROAS. 

To measure the true value of customers, we need to move away from traditional metrics to measure success like CPI and CPM and start looking at the lifetime x daily revenue. 

And depending on your business, this may look different.For example, the longer customer lifecycle for travel may make this 90 days and for gaming it could be as short as 14. Take into account the business, how your customers interact with it and the long-term metrics youre looking to drive to determine this.

You dont have to move through each step here, it is what makes sense to your business.

Potentially actual ROAS is sufficient for you if this is highly representative of the full value you will get from these users but if it isnt then you need to ask if you can make robust decisions and how quickly.

How do I get the most out of my pLTV model?

So you know what LTV is and assuming you believe you should be using it. What do you need to understand about your company's pLTV model to get the most value from it?

The questions to ask and build with you a guide for pLTV.

  • Does a model exist elsewhere in the business? (Data Science, Product, Monetization, CRM)
  • How accurately does the prediction estimate the period I care most about at each point in time?
  • How quickly can I get a prediction? (D1,D3,D7.)
  • What are the inputs to value for the model?
  • Is the model interlinked with my attribution approach? (Cohort models, Acquisition channel variable)
  • Aside from statistical accuracy, how often does the model choose a winning campaign/strategy when compared to other methods?
  • How transparent is the model? Will I understand volatile results? 
  • How well does the model identify different behaviours in my user base (e.g. Whales, Non/late payers)?
  • Does the model generalize well for campaign/game changes? 
  • Is the model dynamic enough to show changes based on engagement activities?

Does a model exist elsewhere in the business?

Now assume the model exists or a new model is being built what do we need to know.

Lets look at this equation again. What are the first questions we ask ourselves?

  1. What is a reasonable definition of lifetime??? Infinity looks great on this equation but we cant wait that long in practice.
  2. What is X? When do I start to predict? How early can I get a prediction and how often do I need to update that prediction?

Knowing your user value curve

You can base your definition of lifetime on a time period that represents a standard lifecycle of your own users. What % of your users remain in the game for X months/ years?

Are there business justifications for assigning an end point? How much value is delivered after day 90,120, 180 etc.?

We want to start predictions as early as possible. As early as gives us a usably accurate prediction. But dont be afraid to update predictions after this as more data comes in.

Two wrongs don't make a right

Your attribution model is a set of rules to determine which users were acquired by which channel. In an ideal world this would be a reasonably accurate assessment of the real users influenced by the campaign on this channel but this may not always be the case.

If you have a cohort approach to predictive LTV where acquisition channel is a key variable you will have a situation where all users acquired by that channel look the same value. You need to ask yourself whether this variable is what makes users more alike than say, in app behaviors.

Common Model Types

  • Spend curve may be estimated based on top down (ignoring distribution of payers), bottoms up (starting with the paying users and aggregating) 
  • Multiplier might be a log or some other function.
  • Cohort level models should be based on rules you believe to be in line with very different value segments.
  • RFM/Buy til you die developed for Ecomm. Small number of specific variables needed but at a user level. Include a churn and a revenue element.
  • Multivariate regression or Machine learning would look at a much larger set of signals including in game features.

All models are wrong, but some are useful

Next, what do we need to know about the model.

Even if you are not the one who, in general, will be building and validating the model accuracy, it doesnt mean you should just accept what ever you are given.

Let's take the example above. You can see the absolute amounts for Model 2 are closer (delta is smaller), but Model 1 chose the right winner.

Im not saying to ignore the model accuracy or how close the actual predictions are, but sometimes accuracy as an aggregate figure can hide different nuances and this is one of the things you want to be able to rely on your model for.

Common Models

Possible model strengths (or weaknesses) you should be aware of.

  • Transparency how much you understand changes in the model will help you to act on the output.
    • If there is a small number of variables or a very simple function underlying the model then it is unlikely to have a lot of volatility and if it does you should be able to pinpoint/diagnose what is driving spikes or drops quite easily. Some (not all) machine learning algorithms are complete black boxes. Try to get insights on the most important factors in your model.
  • Treatment of extremes how does the model handle different groups whales, non-payers vs general paying users. 
    • User level still not perfect BTYD (but till you die model) assumes everyone pays.

Can the model handle change?

Variables that relate well to the users behavior in the game/app are likely to generalize better.

How do you calculate incremental value?

The goal of incrementality measurement is to calculate a lift in ad performance by comparing differences in outcomes between a group of people shown advertising and a comparable control group that wasnt shown ads.

Take the image above as an example of what incremental means:

  • The light blue area indicates the conversions that happened from people who didnt see your advertising.
  • The dark blue indicates the conversions from people who saw your ad and who would have converted on their own.
  • And those conversions in purple are the ones that happened that were directly correlated to seeing your ads.
  • Incrementality is the lift in your business outcomes due to advertising.

And using this value as an input, along with your Average Revenue Per Daily Active User, can better predictive your future LTV. 

Using your predictive LTV value to optimize towards is where a true focus on long-term value and growth comes into play. 

LTV-based measurement impacts relevant
business metrics

A value based approach to marketing positively impacts businesses at a much larger level than just performance marketing metrics.

With the rapid pace of consumer behavior and industry and business change, through a focus on value marketers can better stay focused on their businesses long term sustained growth and rethink strategies beyond customer acquisition.

  • Advertising and marketing reach
  • ROI
  • Impact of management strategies
  • Retention efforts
  • Individual-customer profitability 

People have evolved, business have changed and our marketing efforts should continue to follow suit.

item.title: Proxies in measurement
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
The end goal of all advertising is incremental sales. If advertising isn't changing attitudes/perceptions for sales later (brand) or changing sales behavior now/soon (DR) it's not working.

Right now these changes are captured with heuristics or proxies based on legacy technology of the time; seriously, some TV measurement happens with pen and paper.

These proxies were reasonable shortcuts for their time and place, but their accuracy is eroding more quickly than ever because of mobile. We can and need do better.

The two big proxies in measurement 

The two big proxies are:

Cookie Based Last Click = DR Value. This neglects value from penultimate clicks, cross-device clicks, direct views (aka conversions within minutes or hours), upper funnel prospecting (impressions within weeks), and long term brand equity (impressions that drives sales in the long term).

This is bad for advertisers, because it causes them to overvalue desktop, retargeting, and short-term tactics. A seven-day click window captures, on average, only 60% of true incremental sales and the variance is huge between 0% and 400% of the true ROI.

This is bad for people too: ads chase them around the internet trolling for the last click.

Screen Time = Brand Value. The Brand measurement heuristic assumes all ad screen time (regardless of format) is equally persuasive. That on-screen time = human attention. And that you need somewhere between 6-30 seconds of human attention to 'tell a story' and 'build a brand'.

Yes, all else equal, more time is more better. But media today is more different than it is the same. Phones are not tiny televisions. This heuristic is bad for advertisers: the forced view doesn't actually exist anymore (people scroll through Facebook during TV commercials).

This is bad for people: it created incentives for publishers to make increasingly disruptive and heavy handed advertising (sound-on forced view pre-roll). And, worst, the long-view doesn't actually capture the brand value.

38% of ad recall, 23% of brand awareness, and 35% of the purchase intent are driven by impressions that are not viewable by the MRC video standard. And half the incremental in-store sales lift comes from under the 2 second MRC-viewable standard.

Experiments debunk measurement proxies

 Experiments yield the truth, now and in the future, on any platform.  

Experiments may seem complex but, at the core, they are just coin flipping and subtraction.

Start with your population and flip a coin to divide the population into two groups. Those groups are now guaranteed to the same; the coin isn't more likely to show 'heads' based on that persons income, age, gender, predisposition to buy stuff, people with middle name Bob who like The Rock etc, or whatever variable you care about.

Now give one ads and look at the difference in sales. Because the only difference between the two groups are ads, we know that any observed difference in sales is because of the ads.

If the only difference between the two groups is ads, you know that any observed difference in sales is because of the ads.

Experiments aren't the only to measure incrementality, you can also use fancy math to try infer what would have happened without the ads (Marketing Mix Modeling (MMM), Multi-Touch Attribution (MTA), Synthetic Control Groups (SCG), and many other three letter acronym'd projects try to do this with varying levels of sophistication).

It is possible to a good job here but it is a LOT more work, both from a math perspective and from a marketing perspective. A well designed experiment is harder to execute but also much harder to argue with. If every publisher had a lift tool, measurement would be (relatively) easy, but that isn't the case today. 

We need to accelerate that growth of lift and push the market/industry to do more experimental measurement. We need to put experimental tools directly into the hands of advertisers and do this in a way that is actionable, accessible, and answers their actual marketing questions (without requiring a stats lesson first).

We need to give advertisers a feeling of ownership that increases levels of trust in experimental measurement.

Attribution makes measurement tractable

Experiments yield the truth, now and in the future, on any platform, but they will always come at a cost.

Lift can sow the necessary seed of doubt in the accuracy of the measurement proxies and uncover them as crazy but alone this is not enough. Lift will always come with lost opportunity cost and fail to give granular insights (e.g. creative, media interactions).

Marketers want simple: clear numbers, across all their media, all in one dashboard, updating on a regular drumbeat. Today advertisers care as much about 'apples-to-apples' counting and operational feasibility as accuracy.

So we need to take incremental steps towards incrementality. Proxies persist (and are useful) because they facilitate decisions. 

Today 75% of DR advertisers use Google Analytics for their attribution and decision making.

Google can continue being a proponent of click-only measurement because of their dominance in search (their MTA only uses clicks), and are constantly working to create duration-based standards because of the significant long-duration inventory they have on YouTube (they worked with MRC to make viewability standards).
