item.title: Budget Allocation: Attribution and Lift conundrums
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Attribution vendors face some big challenges today:

  • they rely on cookie based measurement
  • they have less and less visibility of paid media, given the prevalence of walled gardens
  • and are correlation based

For this reason I tend to privilege working with Experimental design (ie. conversion lift) so that we can prove causality in driving business outcomes. That being said, one of the biggest pains about Conversion Lift is that it isnt cross-publisher, as not all marketing channels offer a randomized control test (lift test).

This makes the solution much less actionable for advertisers who are trying to allocate budgets using this tool. The end result is that advertisers go back to attribution based allocation, as this seems to be the easier solution to reconcile results, even though it does not take causality and incremental value of a channel into consideration.   

Moving past click-based attribution and allocating based on incrementality 

The results from Lift tests generally show different numbers what is observed if you were to use a last click model.  The issue however is that the total number of conversions (across all publishers) hasnt actually changed.

So if the number of observed conversions for channel X has gone up, another publisher has to have gone down.but which one?  More importantly, this has implications on budget allocation and therefore is quite the  conundrum for advertisers!

Below I discuss the approach we would take to help advertisers re-allocate conversions (and therefore budget) based on lift.

Note: this is just an approach. I'm sure there are other ways of doing this, but none seem to be posted broadly! It might not be the most accurate but it seems sound.

The numbers below are just for illustrative purposes, however the general process can be followed step by step.

For this example, I've assumed we've done a conversion lift test on Facebook, which is the channel that lets you run a test very easily, whereas other publishers don't provide this tool.

Ideally, we'd like to be able to run lift tests in ALL channels, but unfortunately most of them don't enable advertisers to do this.

 Step. 1: Compare attribution source of truth to lift numbers.

Given the table and chart above you now have shown through lift that Facebook actually cause 1000 more conversions than originally reported on in 1 day Click attribution (1,500 vs 500).

We now have somewhat of a PUZZLE in our hands. Since the total number of conversions is still 10,000, and the number of channels hasnt changed, which publishers have fewer conversions???

Well, lets start with what we know:

A. We have 10,000 conversions

B. Facebook generated 1,500 conversions

C. 8,500 Conversions (10,000-1500) need to be re-allocated in some proportion

The easiest way to re-allocate these conversions is to divide them equally in the proportions that were originally available in click based attribution!

Step 2. Calculating the Share of conversions without Facebook

To do this, we remove Facebook from the original 1 day Click Attribution results and realize that there would have been 9,500 total conversions. At this point we need to find out what % of conversions each channel represents.

We now know the Share of conversions each channel drove!

Step 3. Re-Allocating conversions based on your New Sources of Truth

We now need to apply the rates (share of conversions) we just found to the actual remaining number of conversions (ie. 8500, recall step 1. C ). We should have no qualms about reallocating in this manner for two reasons:

The total number of conversions, 10,000 makes sense to the advertiser. We know this. Its the total number of conversions data.

The number of  conversions that Facebook caused, 1500, should also make sense. After all, this number was obtained through Lift which uses rigorous experimental design.

If however your client (or CMO) is not convinced of this number, then before proceeding we have to ensure/re-explain the lift methodology.

So taking 8,500 as the number of remaining conversions (10,000 total less 1500 caused by Facebook), we divvy these up in the proportions we established in step 2:

Step 4. Pat yourself on the back and have a beer

So there you have it!

  • The total number of conversions has not changed, 10,000 
  • Facebook has Caused 1,500 conversions, measured through lift
  • And we re-allocated conversions in the same proportion as the click based attribution model the client was originally using,  8,500  - 1,500 + 8,500 = 10,000

Now your CMO or client can go ahead and reallocate budget based on these new conversion numbers! 

NOTE: the same can be done even if you are taking ROAS into account, rather than number of conversions. The above process does not change!

item.title: How does creative experience move incremental brand outcomes on Facebook?
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
TL;DR: This is a project we worked on, when I was working at the Marketing Science team at Facebook, and explored the relationship between the creative experience at Facebook ad-level and incremental business outcomes, trying to identify a metric that bridges the gap between them.

The research method was to build a machine learning model to interpret business outcome with creative experience proxy as well as other potential drivers (e.g., optimization, targeting) and then measure the impact of creative by simulation. Uniform Organic Rank*, a normalized version of Organic Bid is used in this research as the creative experience proxy.

The key findings out of this research are:

  • Uniform Organic Rank explains Brand Lift Attribution (BLA) ad recall lift to a certain extent based on the modeling result. It's at the 4th place out of 11 features when ranked by modeling feature importance.
  • Based on model simulation, we found that there is a non-linear relationship between organic rank and ad recall lift. The ad recall lift does not always increase along with organic rank increase. Instead, those two metrics have a stepwise-function style relationship with multiple organic rank jump points. Those jump points could vary by the campaign setup (e.g., optimization, placement, etc.) of an ad. For example, in one simulation we did on Feed with video view optimization and broad targeting, we see that ad recall lift would increase about 5 points if the uniform organic rank of an ad moves from the below-45 to the above-45 bucket.
  • Another finding from the simulation is that even when organic rank is very low, ads still could have decent ad recall lift. This indicates that other campaign factors (e.g., optimization goal, placement, etc.) also play important roles in driving ad recall lift.
  • From the model simulation, we developed a metric which I will call Gamma signal in this post . It measures out of the amount of ad recall lift that could be driven by the creative experience of the ad, how much percent of that has been achieved with the existing creative. It is a metric at ad level with a range from 0 to 100. From the Gamma signal distribution on those brand study ads in this analysis, we found that the majority of ads have room to improve ad recall lift by improving their creative experience (organic rank). The median value of Gamma Signal is 32.5.
  • Breaking down Gamma Signal by vertical, we found that each vertical has their own baseline. Entertainment & Media and Travel vertical have the highest Gamma Signal on average, which indicates that those two verticals don't have much room to improve ad recall lift through a better creative experience. Tech, Financial, and Telecom have relative low Gamma Signal on average, which means there are relatively bigger room for those verticals to improve ad recall lift through better creative experience.

* Please see section What should be the creative experience proxy for phase II? for details of Uniform Organic Rank.

Background

Our goal was to look for a signal (what we are calling Gamma Signal) that captures both the creative experience and the impact on business outcomes of an ad. Creative experience is abstract, but in general refers to the assessment of the experience or fit of an ad to a user's current behavior or mindset. While this may often mean beautiful ads, it won't always be. For business outcome, we focused on incremental outcome such as brand lift.

This project had two phases. Phase I resulted in reviewing all existing creative experience and business outcome signals/metrics that Facebook has. The goal of phase II was to identify the relationship between creative experience of one ad and incremental business outcome and create a signal that bridges the gap between them. For example, given an ad, how does creative experience impact ad recall lift? The research method is to build a model to interpret brand outcome by creative experience as well as other potential drivers.

Why is Gamma Signal useful?

  • It bridges the gap between creative experience and incremental business outcome. A successful campaign could be driven by many factors, such as targeting, objective or creative. To measure this relationship accurately, we currently only have lift study and split tests, but they are not scalable. This project aimed to tease out all the potential drivers of incremental business outcome and then identify the relationship between creative experience and incremental business outcomes.
  • It could be a KPI to measure success of creative from the incremental brand outcome perspective.
  • It is actionable and scalable for all brand campaigns.

If you are interested in reading about the methodology and technical details continue, otherwise skip to the Insights section.

Phase I: Reviewing existing signals/metrics 

First, we reviewed of all the existing creative experience and business outcome signals/metrics. The table below summarizes the findings and conclusion of phase I. The goal of this phase was to identify areas we could use to focus on when developing the actual Gamma Signal in phase II.

The key metrics to focus on are highlighted in green in the above table. Main takeaways that can be used for phase II are 

  • Creative experience
    • AWR component of Organic Bid (roughly contributes 80% of Organic Bid) is the only qualified existing signal to test in phase II since it's the only one that is scalable. AWR is measured based on one survey question: How much do you want to see this ad in your News Feed?. However, this question does not measure everything of creative experience.
    • Organic Bid is not comparable across ads directly since it contains user dollar value implicitly. This signal is at the impression level. The values of organic bid of one ad bidding on different users could be very different. Therefore, certain normalization is necessary before any test.
  • Business outcome
    • Brand
      • eARL: Available for all brand campaigns at impression level
      • BLA: Available for all campaigns with brand lift study at ad and placement level
    • DR
      • FIA: Available for all DR campaigns at impression level

What is the creative experience proxy for phase II?

A metric called Uniform Organic Rank is selected as the proxy. It's a normalized Organic Bid by daily auction.

For one ad, it looks at each individual auction that ad competed in and where it was in the top 50 ads in the auction (even if it didn't win an impression). It then reranks those ads by Organic Bid only to get the "rank" of the ad for the auction.

The average of this rank across all auctions for the ad is called the average organic rank. The metric uniform organic rank converts the average to a percentile based on the distribution of average organic rank for all ads on one day. Theoretically, if average organic rank follows a Gaussian Distribution, its percentile should be close to a uniform distribution.

That's why it's called uniform organic rank. An ad with a uniform organic rank value 60 means the ad is less competitive on organic bid, relative to its competitors, than 40% of ads, relative to their competitors

Uniform Organic Rank only measures the relative ads quality instead of absolute quality. For one ad, its Uniform Organic Rank could be driven by factors such as other ads that it competes with or the relevance of its targeting audience.

For instance, a good creative might have a low Uniform Organic Rank if it targets a low relevance audience. Moreover, Uniform Organic Rank does not capture all the information of creative experience since it's too difficult (almost impossible) to compress all the information of creative experience into just an integer.

Although this metric is not perfect, it is still a good one to start with since it's a metric calculated based on Organic Bid which is used in our delivery system. If we found any solid relationship between it and business outcome, moving it could affect campaign delivery and then improve performance directly.

The histogram in above illustrates the distribution of average uniform organic rank of brand lift study ads from.

One caveat of this average uniform organic rank is that since it is calculated at daily basis, it could vary a lot day by day for one ad, especially for long-term campaign. So, this metric might not be that accurate for ads in long-term campaign.

Phase II Methodology Deep Dive

I started with brand campaigns since I think creative plays a more important role in brand than DR campaigns according to past research I've done.

Theoretically, the best method is to test the creative experience proxy in either eARL or BLA model directly. However, both modeling frameworks are complex and at a granular level.

It's expensive and not flexible for this research (especially for running simulations) of which the goal is to do measurement only at the ad level.

Therefore, this research takes a step further to explore if there is any non-linear relationship. Our research method is to build a machine learning model to interpret estimated brand lift outcomes (e.g., ad recall) at the ad level. A successful campaign is usually driven not only by creative, but also many other factors, such as objective, targeting, etc. These factors work together to drive the final outcome. In order to tease out the effectiveness of creative experience accurately, we need to take into account as many potential drivers as possible when modeling. Then, we can simulate the impact of creative experience by controlling other drivers and observing the change in outcome.

We used BLA estimated ad recall lift as the outcome metric since it is owned by my team.

Step 1: Identify drivers

Including the Uniform Organic Rank, we tested the following drivers/features in our model.

  • Uniform Organic Rank
  • Vertical & Sub Vertical
  • Creative Format
  • Bid Type
  • Optimization Goal
  • Targeting Type
  • Placement
  • Business Region
  • GSO / SMB
  • CPM
  • Frequency
  • 3s View Rate

Step 2: Modeling

  • Dataset: Model is built at ad_id (EntAd) and placement (page_type) level with the following filtering criteria on ad_id: legal impression >= 100K; CPM >= $0.1; daily auctions competed >= 500
  • Time Window: Includes Facebook brand lift studies from 2018/03/23 to 2018/05/23 globally which comes out to about 2,000 studies and over 14,000 ads in total
  • Validation Dataset: Randomly sampled 30% of cell_id's for validation
  • Machine Learning Method: GBDT Regression from scikit-learn package 
  • Target: BLA Ad Recall Lift
  • Hyper-parameter Sweeping: Learning rate is selected by 3-fold cross-validation on training dataset
  • Feature Selection: Select features based on GBDT feature importance and practical business knowledge. Features in the final model are
    • 3s View Rate
    • Business Region
    • CPM
    • Creative Format
    • Frequency
    • Optimization Goal
    • Placement
    • Targeting Type
    • Uniform Organic Rank
    • Vertical
  • Model Prediction Performances: The result in the above chart is calculated from that 30% holdout dataset. R^2 confidence interval is calculated by bootstrapping the holdout data. Overall, the model has good predictive power. It could be used to either interpret or predict BLA ad recall lift.

Insights

How important is organic rank as a feature in the model?

Uniform Organic Rank does explain the variance of BLA ad recall lift to certain extent based on the GBDT feature importance. The importance of a feature is computed as the (normalized) total information for prediction brought by that feature.

How does organic rank impact ad recall lift?

Let's answer this question by simulation. Say we are setting up a brand campaign with the following features.

  • Optimization Goal: Video View Optimization
  • Placement: Mobile Feed Only
  • Business Region: US
  • Creative Format: Video
  • Targeting: Broad
  • For CPM, Frequency and 3s View Rate the average value of historical brand lift campaigns (from 2018/03/23 to 2018/05/23) by corresponding optimization goal, placement, business region and creative format is used.

The only two variables that vary are uniform organic rank and vertical. We simulated how ad recall lift moves while organic rank increases from 0 to 99 by vertical. Chart 4 below has the simulation curve of three verticals and one average curve across all verticals.

From the simulation result, we found that

  • Even when organic rank is very low, we could still have decent ad recall lift. This indicates that other campaign factors (e.g., optimization goal, placement) also play an important role in driving ad recall lift.
  • The relationship is non-linear between organic rank and ad recall lift. The ad recall lift does not always increase along with organic rank. Instead, these two metrics have a step function style relationship. In the simulation chart, each simulation curve has several jump points of organic rank. For example, ad recall lift would increase about 5 points if the uniform organic rank of an ad move from the below-45 to the above-45 bucket.
  • When organic rank is greater than 90, ad recall lift decreases a bit. This is an interesting finding from this simulation. We guess the reason could be the following.
    • Creative that is too native/relevant might not optimize ad recall lift. 
    • High organic rank could be driven by high relevance of targeting audience. Those users might have relative low marginal incremental impact. For instance, if a client targets on its loyal customers/heavy user, the incremental ad recall could be small due to their high recall baseline. In other words, sometimes it's hard to make a heavy user heavier through marketing.
    • The sample size of ads with organic rank greater than 90 is much smaller than lower rank values, though still big enough for analysis (about 300 examples). The estimation on this upper-end range of organic rank may not be as accurate as other values.
  • The difference between max and min simulated lifts varies by vertical. The table below shows that the overall average difference is about 7.3%. Entertainment & Media has the biggest difference, 10.9% and CPG has the lowest, 6.5%. This value estimates the max impact (ad recall lift) that creative could drive through creative experience.
  • Caveat: This is just a simulation of one campaign scenario which is used to give us a taste on the relationship between organic rank and ad recall lift. Since GBDT model can capture the interaction effect among features, the shape of the curve would change when the campaign setup of an ad changes.

In order to tease out the relationship between ad recall lift and organic rank of each ad, we need to do this simulation for each ad and then convert the outcome curve into a scaler metric. We call this metric the Gamma Signal. 

What is Gamma Signal?

Before we create the Gamma Signal, let's define a very important metric called Max Impact of Organic Rank (MIOR). MIOR of one ad is defined as the difference between the max and the min simulated lift by changing organic rank from 0 to 99 and controlling other features. It represents a theoretical max impact of creative simulated by model.

The table above has the MIOR by vertical of the simulation scenario we did above. The higher the MIOR, the more ad recall lift that one ad could drive through creative experience.

Now that we have the MIOR concept, we define the Gamma Signal as a normalized MIOR. It measures the percentage of MIOR one ad gained.

In other words, one ad with Gamma Signal x means that out of the amount of ad recall lift that could be driven by creative experience of the ad, x% of that has been achieved by its existing creative. It's a relative metric with range from 0 to 100. Below is the pseudo code of creating Gamma Signal.

for each ad_id:

    for i in [0 to 99]: 

        lift_sim[i] = simulated ad recall lift with orangic_rank value i by controlling other features

    lift = BLA estimation with the actual organic rank value of the ad_id

    lift_min = the minimum value of lift_sim

    lift_max = the maximum value of lift_sim

    MIOR = lift_max - lift_min

    X_signal[ad_id] = 100 * (lift - lift_min) / MIOR

This Gamma Signal histogram illustrates that the majority of brand campaign ads have room to improve ad recall lift by improving creative (organic rank).

The median value of Gamma Signal is 32.5 which indicates that there is about 60% of MIOR can be improved on average for one ad.

Gamma Signals vary vertical by vertical. The table above calculates the quantiles of Gamma Signal by vertical.

Entertainment & Media and Travel vertical are on the top of this table, which indicates that those two verticals don't have much room to improve ad recall lift through a better creative experience.

Technology, Financial Services, and Telecom are at the bottom, which means there is relatively more room for those verticals to improve ad recall lift through better creative experience.

Is Gamma Signal Linearly correlated with Organic Rank?

Though created through organic rank, the Gamma Signal is not highly correlated with Uniform Organic Rank (Pearson r = 0.36). A high uniform organic rank won't guarantee a high Gamma Signal.

Again, this is more evidence of the complexity of a campaign. A successful campaign is always driven by many factors synergistically (e.g., creative, targeting, placement, optimization). 

Gamma Signal is a relative metric

The Gamma Signal is calculated based on Uniform Organic Rank which is a relative rank metric. The rank of one ad does not reflect its absolute ad quality.

It reflects how relevant an ad is to its targeting audience compared with other ads that target the same audience. A good creative with bad targeting might lead to low organic rank.

Moreover, the Gamma Signal is also calculated based on an ad's existing campaign setup (e.g., objective, placement, targeting). If the setup changes, the value of the Gamma Signal might change as well.

Creative Examples with High and Low Gamma Signal

Based on the value of Gamma Signal and Uniform Organic Rank, creatives can be classified into four quadrants.

We looked at many creatives in each quadrant and tried to summarize the creative style of each quadrant in a clear and neat pattern.

However, we found that there is still some noise in each quadrant. After all, Uniform Organic Rank is just a scaler metric which does not contain all the information of creative experience, though it is the most robust signal that Facebook currently has for this type of quality measure.

There are still many nuances of creative that are hard to measure and capture.

For each quadrant, we picked one creative from the auto vertical as example to illustrate some creative patterns we found.

Ads detail

  • High Gamma Signal & High Organic Rank
    • Gamma Signal: 66.6
    • Organic Rank: 50.6
    • BLA Ad Recall Lift: 14.7%
  • High Gamma Signal & Low Organic Rank
    • Gamma Signal: 70.4
    • Organic Rank: 8.1
    • BLA Ad Recall Lift: 18.7%
  • Low Gamma Signal & High Organic Rank
    • Gamma Signal: 10.1
    • Organic Rank: 36.9
    • BLA Ad Recall Lift: 29.9%
  • Low Gamma Signal & Low Organic Rank
    • Gamma Signal: 7.5
    • Organic Rank: 3.4
    • BLA Ad Recall Lift: 17.4%

item.title: [draft] How to measure attention: a currency for the attention economy
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Time spent on a channel has been a metric that advertisers measure as a proxy for measuring outcomes that really matter.

But time spent doesn't equate attention. So, how do you measure attention?

To tackle this problem, me and my team have been running eye tracking studies desktop and mobile. We use cross media pre-testing and tracking tools, implement programmatic integrations, and link the studies to sales.

The Attention Funnel: A New Metric for a New Media Age

Using eye-tracking studies, we can actually put a number to how many ads actually get looked at.

We like to think of it as an attention funnel.

At the top of the funnel is how many impressions you buy as an advertiser. The first thing you have to assess is how many of these are viewable: how many people actually open the page of a newspaper, or are in the room when the TV ad plays out, or load in a viewable position on a computer or phone. 

The second thing is to count how many people actually looked at the ad and assess the proportion of people who could see the ad who did see the ad. 

But how long did they look at the ad for? We also have to work out the depth of engagement with the ad. If someone looked at it for a second or a minute. 

And to give us a single score, we can multiply the percentage who viewed the ad with the average dwell time they spent with it to create a single unit of advertising attention: the attentive seconds per 1000 impressions.

And clever advertisers can combine this number with pricing information to create an attentive cost per thousand or aCPM, which can be used to assess the relative value of different media opportunities.

Some cross media comparisons

Lets have a look at how this works in practice, looking at desktop display, mobile display and print display data from the UK.

As you can see here, not all mobile ads are viewable, and of the ones that are, not all of them get viewed. Only around 18% of desktop advertising actually gets looked at, for about 1.6 seconds on average.

This means for every 1000 digital display ads you buy, you get about 150 seconds of attention in total about 2 and half minutes. 

For mobile, the picture is a bit better for mobile ads. If mobile ads are viewable, then they are much more likely to be seen.

However, people scroll down mobile pages so quickly that the ads are seen for a shorter amount or time. This means that you get around 327 seconds per thousand for most mobile ads. 

Press is a bit better. If you open the page, then the ad is 100% viewable, but by our estimates only 65% of the pages get opened. Its also pretty likely to be viewed. And crucially, its likely to be viewed for a relatively long time: 2 seconds plus in most cases. You get over 1000 seconds of attention per thousand impressions for press ads: over seven times the attention you get from a typical desktop ad.

Media buyers can use this data to assess the relative impact of placing ads in different media. Creative agencies can use this data to understand what attention budgets they actually have to play with.

Viewability by media varies greatly  

As you can see below, viewability of video advertising varies greatly across media.

Data from TVision shows that many TV ads are not viewable, but they play out to empty rooms!

As seen in the chart below, viewability viewing: sometimes more, sometimes less.

Just because an ad is viewable does not mean that it is viewed. But sometimes the reverse is true: ads that are not technically viewable do in fact get looked at.

For TV ads, someone can be in the room (meaning that the ad is viewable) but not looking at the screen.

For social media ads, the ads can be on screen, and get some attention, but not reach the 2 sec threshold that qualifies them to be technically viewable.

Dwell time varies dramatically between media

The amount of time that people spend actively looking at ads varies greatly across media. TV ads, and some YouTube formats, get enough attention tell a story. Everything else, including social media, might get very little attention.

Attentive seconds per 1000 impressions provides a single unit of attention to compare across media

We can combine viewability, view rate and dwell time into a single number to compare across media.

Viewability rate (%) x viewing rate (%) x av. Dwell time (sec) x 1000 = Attentive seconds per 1000 impressions.

The high viewability and view rates for YouTube mean that it produces significant amounts of attentive seconds, even though dwell times are low compared to TV.

Adding in cost per thousand helps us understand the cost of attention 

We can apply cost per thousand (CPM) data to help understand the cost of the attention that advertisers buy

These costs are indicative only and adapted from estimates compiled and published by Dr Augustine Fou.

How much does it cost to get 1000 to view an ad?

We can apply the CPM estimates to the viewing rate for different media to understand the cost of getting 1000 views irrespective of time. This is the approach adopted by Route, the Out-of-home measurement in the UK.

How much does it cost to buy 1000 seconds of attention? 

We then combine the CPM with the attentive second per 1000 impressions to create an attentive CPM or aCPM.

This shows that while TV advertising may look expensive on a CPM basis, it can in fact be a cheap way of buying attention .

item.title: [draft]How charging higher prices for your product might lead to higher customer satisfaction
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Heh, that headline isnt a typo

This is a deep and wide topic so Im sharing some food for thought as people ramp up in this area

Point of view:When were talking about pricing and packaging, what were really talking about is helping customersmake a decision.Understanding how customers make decisionsis the key to unlocking their choice. Consumer decisions are highly contextual and generally consider tradeoffs compared to their next best available option, but theyre not always rational.

To start, think about how YOU make decisions to buy a product. What is most important to you?

If youre like most customers, you might weigh various considerations. There are objective elements like price, features, availability but also subjective elements like trust, taste, feeling, etc. These intangible forces function as x-factors for choice, leading to brand preference. We dont know which of these elements are most important to a specific customer and it may vary based on the situation or industry. Are there other elements that might be specific to our category?

We are selling a technical product and the level of digital literacy among our customers may vary. When people dont fully understand what they are buying, they usually do one or more of the following: 1) research before deciding, 2) seek recommendations from people they know, or 3) make gut-driven decisions based on proxies for trust. Here is an example of building proxies for trust

How nice is your mechanic? In a previous life, I did extensive research in the auto repair industry. We analyzed the pricing, customer satisfaction, and technical certifications for thousands of mechanics. People often worry they will be overcharged, but I learned that the mechanics who (over)charged higher prices also had the highest satisfaction rates. How could this be? The reality is that many customers are not able to evaluate the technical ability of their mechanic so they look for other signals: How many positive reviews does this shop have? Do I know someone whos been to this shop before? How nice is the person Im dealing with?

Commanding a premium:Almost all of these shops invested in a friendly yet effectiveservice advisorrole whose goal was to quickly build trust, explain complicated stuff, and make the customer feel heard. In exchange, the shop could command higher pricing and more effectively upsell (this was a fascinating study and Id be happy to talk about it in more detail if anyone wants to geek out!).

///////A good parallel here might be theDIFMdo it for me program. We are also able to charge a premium for the trust in our brand and several customers express a preference to work directly with us because they know we wont disappear with their deposit.////////

Learnings from recent price testing:

/////Last year, we did a bunch of testing to see if we could influence the plan mix. We removed some plans and changed the prices of others to understand elasticity. It was difficult to move customers up to the next plan, at least upfront (the exception was Japan). Some customers would specifically ask for a plan by name if they didnt see it listed anymore, which means some people did do research and already know which plan they want. We learned that our current price points are roughly optimized to balance conversion and monetization yield, though there is an opportunity at a country level for further right pricing.You can go down this rabbit hole to learn more./////////

Thought starters:

These are a collection of unproven theories, open questions, and ideas based on previous testing and research that are yet to be explored. They are meant to spark discussion, feel free to discuss in the comments!

  • I dont think most customers understand the features they are buying (with exception of some savvy business plan users), and we may have an opportunity to help them make informed choices and build trust. If youve never managed a website before, you may not understand the full value of managed hosting with automated backups or automatic version upgrades, for example. The trick is how do we explain this with limited real estate on the pages where people need to make a decision?
  • I think certain features might be more important to customers than others when picking a plan but Im not sure were always highlighting the right ones or bundling them into plans most effectively. Alternatively, if people dont realize they want certain features until later on, should we be giving them away upfront for free or upsell them later when they need it? Are we talking about features in terms of real-world benefits, in a way that the average customer can understand?
  • Other hosts like to show very low entry level price points and then upsell a LOT. While some people might see this as nickle and diming, some customers like the idea of fully customizing a plan and paying for only what they need. Should we match them, go in another direction to sell bundled value, or is it possible to do both? Lowering prices tends to generate higher conversion rates but you also yield less per customer, so what is the right balance for sustainability?
  • I think that we might accidentally drive our power customers away because it is not cost-effective to host multiple sites with us so it makes sense to leave once they scale site counts. A surprisingly high % of current subscription conversions are second purchases from existing users and it might be good to validate and explore this a bit more (I dont have the stat handy).
  • Im not sure plan names make as big of a difference as we think they do. For example, think about your mobile cell plan (if you have one). Do you know the name of your plan? Did it impact your choice? Likely, the answer is no. You probably picked the plan that met your needs regardless of the name. You might have even added a friend to your famly plan (dont worry, I wont tell). We might have a lot to learn from telcoms who take a modular approach to creating new plans and have flexibility to change their offerings.
  • We have an opportunity to further drop pricing in non-US markets, validated by our testing in Mexico and India and could be a quick win. I noticed some other companies have started showing non-US pricing as strike outs and mentioning its a promotional country level price. This might also be an interesting way to handle price testing so we dont have legacy issues when some cohorts are renewed at different prices and it gives us optionality to change it back.

Let me know if you have any questions, comments, or ideas. I would be happy to brainstorm further or help procure historical information about any of this.

item.title: [draft] Lifecycle strategy GrowthMarketing
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
What the heck is lifecycle anyway?

Most buying decisions dont happen on the first encounter with a brand. Customers arent sure right away if well meet their needs. Winning customers takes time, multiple touch points, and trust that builds over time.

Lifecycle marketing is a marketing strategy that includes all of these touch points over customer journeys. Understanding our users, their points of friction and knowing the right mental models is core to how we attract, activate, upgrade, retain and get customers to invite their friends. 

Most lifecycle strategies exist to create a seamless, personalized experience for customers across messaging channels like email, SMS, mobile push, web push, in-app notifications, social and more. 

Mission statement

Acting as the empathy barometer for our users in every touch point, our teams mission is to help build memorable, personalized customer experiences through education and storytelling to drive growth and engagement for WordPress.com. 

To build these experiences, well work closely with several cross functional teams with a long-term strategy that will have the simple goal of getting the right message to the right users at the right time, personalized to their goals, needs and behaviours. 

The more improvements we can drive in educating and providing value to our customers, the more likely they are to upgrade/grow and become long time customers. These efforts will result in compounding business impact that we will see across all of our other marketing efforts as this improvement on the bottom of the funnel health will boost all other channels. 

Focus areas

To help accelerate the growth of the business and with our Growth Flywheel in mind, well play a key role in saving customers at specific steps and increasing average customer value.

Were still playing with these areas and will update as we identify new gaps, but most of our projects will be collaborative and are going to fall under 6 areas: 

  1. Personalized email campaigns and flows
  2. Multi-channel messaging
  3. User insights and journey mapping
  4. Campaign performance and reporting
  5. Email infra and process
  6. Other bets

1 Personalized email campaigns and automated flows

Email is our biggest opportunity and our core focus area. Ensuring our email touchpoints are cohesive, clear, consistent, and compelling. This means building personalized flows based on who the user is, what the user has, or hasnt done. All of these projects are cross functional and will involve many stakeholders.

Onboarding and adoption

  • New user onboarding flows for free users
  • Paying subscribers, monthly, annual onboarding flows
  • Customer education programs

Expansion, support, loyalty

  • Monthly flash sale campaigns
  • Cross-sell/upgrade campaigns
  • Loyalty/advocacy flows
  • Community programs

Churn, win back focus

  • Winback emails
  • Cancellation flows and saving customers
  • Reactivation flows, abandoned carts
  • Renewal emails
  • Re-engagement: Happy moments, delightful experiences and messaging
  • Improving Refund Experience

2 Multi-channel messaging

Building out multi-channel messaging capabilities. Right now we rely heavily on email as the primary channel to communicate the onboarding and educational messaging with our users. In collaboration with +dinobotsp2 and other teams, we want to take our lifecycle marketing strategy and incorporate in-product messaging, nudges, and for users who have our app; push notifications, in-app notifications, and SMS. 

Examples of potential projects we could explore today:

  • Leveraging pipe for more timely messaging
  • Integrating Pipe directly into our marketing tactics and strategies
  • Different pricing within product for JITMs and nudges

3 User insights and mapping their journeys

In partnership with several customer facing teams and leveraging existing customer research, well help map out the customer journey while ensuring our touchpoints are cohesive, clear, consistent, and compelling. As we roll out new touchpoints, well make sure that they are incorporated into the overall journey to build an experience that is optimized for our users.

Our hope is to be an integral part of everything onboarding to help customers get the most value out of their experience with us and cover any educational/upgrade gaps along the way.

Well also work to figure out ways to ask users for feedback about their goals, what type of site they are trying to build, their challenges, and more. The more questions we can ask our users to get feedback around what they are trying to accomplish with WordPress.com, the more we can tailor our messaging to their specific needs. 

4 Campaign performance and reporting

In partnership with +dinobotsp2 and Growth Analytics (@ngdeb and team), own the auditing of existing campaign performance, launching experiments, identifying areas for opportunity and optimization based on customer insights and campaign analysis. Includes email and JITM reporting dashboards.

5 Email infrastructure and process

In partnership with +martechp2, guide the development and roadmap of our in-house email platform to ensure we can scale our lifecycle marketing capabilities while ensuring that we are able to accurately track and measure performance of campaigns and tactics. This includes email process projects that would help define the steps to send emails or build campaigns to streamline product and other incoming requests.

6 Other bets

This is an exploratory category of projects that touch emerging channels and opportunities ripe for experimentation. We could explore things like:

  • Message sending time optimization
  • Location-based messages 
  • AI-powered copy optimization 
  • Immersive AR experiences 
  • Live video email
  • Much more

Main channels

  • Email
  • In-app messages/notifications/nudges (JITMs)
  • Mobile push notifications
  • Chat
  • SMS
  • Third party tools

Teams well work closely with

Most of our projects will be highly collaborative and well lean on the expertise of different teams. 

Note: this isnt an exhaustive list, there will be plenty of opportunity for collaboration within the company. 

Marketing:

  • +dinobotsp2 (Martech) for everything communication ops (i.e., email marketing, email platform development, JITMs, and SMS)
  • +communitygrowthp2 and +experientialmktg for everything community, sponsorships and conferences as well as corporate communications, everything social media, proactive and reactive announcements
  • +monetizationteam for lifecycle projects relating to +difmp2 and other partnership opportunities
  • +editorialp2 and +creativep2 for help polishing our messaging prose and everything storytelling 
  • Growth Analytics (@ngdeb and team) for help improving, building, and optimizing our data analysis of lifecycle activities

Design:

  • +dotcomdesignp2 Well work in tandem with product designers on the dotcom design team for any customer facing projects

Infrastructure (Bridge)

  • +decisionsciencep2 (Data team) on projects that touch Explat/Abacus and Pipe
  • +a8cpayments (Payments team) on projects that touch checkout and payment user flows

Forge

  • +explorersp2 (Manage focus) for projects relating to helping customers accomplish their goals post-signup, with a focus on increasing engagement and revenue
  • +teamlunap2 (Create focus) for projects that touch everything signup & site creation flows

Apps

  • +puffinp2 (Nighthawk) for everything dotcom mobile apps

Happiness 

  • +happops for any projects and campaigns that would impact HEs to make sure we have resources to cover ticket queues

Metrics well be impacting and monitoring

With our Growth Flywheel in mind, well play a key role in saving customers at specific steps and increasing average customer value, aside from experiment results, these are some of the metrics well be closely monitoring:

  • 24H / 7D Signup conversion rate
  • 24H / 7D Purchase conversion rate
  • 24H Signup Conversion, by Mobile App
  • 24H Purchase Conversion Counts
  • Average Purchase Value From New Subscribers
  • Existing Subscribers Purchasing New Products
  • Trend of cancelling auto-renewal by the toggle
  • Monthly trend of self-serving cancelling purchases
  • Subscriber Retention Rate
  • Active WordPress.com Users by Plan
  • Users of the WordPress mobile apps
  • More to come as we discover Looker and Tracks!

Upcoming project pipeline

  • Improve onboarding messages for first 30D lifecycle
    • This is our main communication channel once someone signups as a customer. We send roughly 3x less email than competitors and there is room to improve the quality of our content to guide users to success. 
    • https://growthchannels.wordpress.com/2021/01/08/project-thread-rebuild-and-test-lifecycle-email-flows-for-first-30-days/ 
  • Improve monthly promo sale efficacy with better offers, placement, and targeting
    • Currently we generated about $150K/mo due to flash sales but I think we can possibly double this with some optimizations. We have a large portion of our audience that is no longer responsive to the current offers, so we should try some new approaches and targeting. 
    • https://growthchannels.wordpress.com/2021/01/28/pt-ml-sales-campaigns-2021/ 
  • Re-engage and save customers at specific steps
    • Were including in this section projects that focus on a specific step of the customer journey to drive engagement. Projects like cancellation and win-back flows, abandoned cart emails, driving engagement for webinars and much more.
    • Well be collaborating with a few pods, namely Blogger Design, Flow patrol and Happiness Gardeners. 

Wed love to hear from you and cant wait to get going!

item.title: [draft] Building Lyfts Marketing Automation Platform
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
https://eng.lyft.com/lyft-marketing-automation-b43b7b7537cc

We take pride in our mission to improve peoples lives with the worlds best transportation. More than 50 million carbon neutral Lyft rides happen every month across the US and Canada and weve barely scratched the surface in the potential for rideshare.

Part of our growth is improvements in our acquisition process like launching region-specific ad campaigns that increase awareness, and consideration of our multi-modal offerings. Coordinating these campaigns to acquire new users at scale has become time-consuming, leading us to take on the challenge of automation.

Growth Acquisition

Acquisition is typically led by a data-driven cross-functional team that focuses on scale, measurability, and predictability. You may have seen Lyft ads like these:

Acquisition operates at the top and largest part of the onboarding funnel, through the various channels listed on the left. No two channels are created equal: we work with different partners, technologies, and strategies to make sure that Lyft is the top choice for consumers. Other teams at Lyft focus on different parts of the user journey to provide a world-class experience. A high-level view is shown below.

Motivation

Acquiring users at scale means making thousands of decisions each day, for each region where Lyft operates: choosing bids, budgets, creatives, incentives, and audiences; running tests; and more. Just keeping up with these repeated tasks occupies a great deal of marketers mindshare and can lead to suboptimal decisions. Its expensive to the business and does not scale.

By automating routine decisions, we can scale efficiently and create a data-driven learning system. This also lets marketers concentrate on innovation and experimentation instead of operational activities.

Path to Automation

Our goal: build a marketing automation platform to improve cost and volume efficiency while enabling our marketing team to run more complex, high-impact experiments.

Requirements:

  1. Ability to predict the likelihood of a new user to engage with our product.
  2. Measurement mechanisms to allocate our marketing budgets across different internal and external channels.
  3. Levers to deploy these budgets across thousands of ad campaigns.

Marketing performance data contributes to a feedback loop to constantly nourish the reinforcement-learning system.

Here are examples of problems we needed to automate:

  • Updating bids across thousands of search keywords.
  • Turning off poor-performing display creative.
  • Changing referrals values by market.
  • Identifying high-value user segments.
  • Sharing learnings from different strategies across campaigns.

And so, we created Symphony an orchestration system that takes a business objective, predicts future user value, allocates budget, and publishes that budget to drive new users to Lyft.

Architecture

The Symphony architecture consists of three main components: lifetime value (LTV) forecaster, budget allocator, and bidders.

Our tech stack comprises Apache Hive, Presto, an internal machine learning (ML) platform, Airflow, and third-party APIs. A light front-end feeds in business targets and launches creatives. The architecture has a lot of moving parts and dependencies and requires rigorous logging and monitoring. We dive deeper into each component below.

Lifetime Value (LTV) forecaster

Understanding the potential value of a user is critical to every business. The goal of this component is to measure the efficiency of various acquisition channels based on the value of the users coming from those channels. Budget can then be allocated based on the expected value for users coming from a given channel and the price we are willing to pay in a particular region for those types of users.

The above diagram portrays at a high level how we calculate a users expected LTV while accounting for supply and demand in our two-way marketplace. We try our best to predict LTV accurately, as it helps us set mid- to long-term strategic goals.

Early in the users lifecycle, it is hard to get a sense of their retention, rides, or transaction value, so instead of attempting to measure LTV directly, we predict it from historical data. The forecast improves as the user interacts with our services.

The benchmark here represents average expected LTV from a cohort of users. These forecasts feed into the budget allocator and help it decide the value of users that come from a specific set of campaigns.

Budget allocator

The budget allocator collects marketing performance data in conjunction with LTV forecasts. Budget allocations are done using Markov chain Monte Carlo (Thompson Sampling). A curve of the form LTV = a * (spend)^b is fit to the data assuming a & b come from distributions with their own parameters (e.g. a comes from a distribution with mean a and standard deviation a ). Heres the trick we dont try to estimate a & b directly as you would in standard regression. Instead, we estimate the parameters of their distributions: (a, a) & (b, b). Consequently, instead of drawing a curve with fixed a & b, each day we sample a different estimate of a & b from these distributions naturally injecting a degree of randomness into our cost-curve creation process.

This type of random searching may seem wasteful, but modest exploration is actually optimal in the long run. It helps us explore points in the curve we would have not normally considered to converge to a global optimum.

The budget allocator sends each campaigns allocation to the respective channel bidder for deployment.

Bidders

Bidders publish the final changes needed to serve an ad at the target price point. Bidders are made up of two parts the tuners and actors. The tuners decide how to deploy the capital based on available levers (e.g keyword, title, value, bid type for Google Search), while also considering channel-specific context. The actors communicate the actual bid to the internal and external channels like Job Boards, Search, Display, Social, and Referrals through API integrations.

Over the years we have built relationships with our partners who help get our product in front of the right audience. Each channel, based on its level of sophistication, supports different bidding strategies. Some popular strategies are listed below.

Were constantly experimenting to set each campaigns bid with the right strategy and update cadence in an ever-changing digital media landscape.

Bidders contain a lot of channel-specific nuances that help them make the best possible decision. The bidders also have some level of recency weighting and seasonality baked in to account for market volatility.

Conclusion

The long-term success of marketing automation at Lyft depends on incorporating human feedback into our machine learning platforms. This is generally referred to as human-in-the-loop machine learning, and enables machines to work on automation-breadth problems while empowering human operators to focus on knowledge-dependent problems. Without good input from the humans driving the automation engine, the quality of the models will suffer (garbage in, garbage out).

Without the cognitive overhead of manually updating bids or allocating budgets, we expect our marketing teams to more nimbly apply audience and creative changes to campaigns. They have more time and energy to:

  • Understand our users and their interests
  • Ideate new ad formats, messaging & channels
  • Form hypotheses for big shots on goals

We have many exciting ideas for the continued iterations to Symphony:

  • Always-on experimentation
  • Incorporating seasonal effects like weather & time of day
  • Better marketplace context to inform our bidders
  • Intelligent segmentation & personalization

With Symphony, we are achieving a higher return on our investments while saving marketer hours. The system powers a growing ecosystem of more than 30 million riders and close to 2 million drivers (based on 2018 data). Marketing automation is still in its nascency at Lyft, and while these methodologies have helped us scale so far, we will continue learning and improving as we grow. We are excited for our bright machine learning and experimentation driven future.

item.title: [draft] GeoX: An introduction to Geo Experiments
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Geo experiments help determine incrementality and lift in settings where it is difficult to target and segment at the user-level. They are mainly used in asserting efficiency of ad campaigns. Geo experiments rely on complicated statistical heavy lifting in the background.

The most rigorous method of measurement is a randomized experiment such as an A/B test. In these experiments, each user is assigned to a control or treatment group and the subsequent user behavior is compared to determine the incremental impact of a change. However, in acquisition setting we do not have access to this user-level data and issues with cookies further complicate such analyses.

A geo experiment is like an A/B test but uses geographies to define your control and treatment group rather than individuals or web cookies. In geo experiments, geographic regions are divided into treatment and control group. The regions in the treatment group are exposed to a marketing intervention while regions in the control group remain status quo.

The marketing intervention happens for a duration of time and the response metric is observed. The idea is to detect if there is an incremental lift in the response metric in the treatment regions which can only be done through rigorous statistical modelling.(Ref)

Geo experiments are also privacy-friendly since the outcomes of interest are aggregated across each geographic region in the experiment. No individual user-level information is required for the pure geo experiments and hence it alsomitigates issues like inadequate cookie or browser tracking.

Geo experiment design & structure

Geo experiments rely on three things:

1. Segmenting a geographic area (such as a country) into a set of sub-regions, or geos.

Our available geos can be cities or other sub-regions in a country, such as DMAs in the US, States in the US, or cities in Italy  these examples now are all supported by the internal framework [1].

  •  It must be possible for the intervention under test to individually target each geo.
  • Once the set of experiment geos is specified, they are assigned to Treatment and Control groups.
  • The assignment to Treatment and Control can be randomized (possibly using stratification), or matched, or anything in between, depending on the requirements and the analysis method that will be used.
  • We assume that the two groups behave similarly, and that the Control geo acts as a good predictor for the behavior of the Treatment geo.
  • We also assume that any change in Control, such as seasonal or product changes, will be equally observed in the Treatment group both in the pretest and the test period.

The randomized assignment of a large number of geos provides the most protection against known and unknown differences across geos, while a matched market test deliberately assigns as few as one geo (e.g., a single DMA or US State) to the treatment group and one to control. (Ref)

  • Via internal testing, we have found that matched market tests with fewer geos (e.g. country-level data) do not work as well (or at all) as a more granular DMA or state-level look.
  • However, we have found mostly acceptable results for stratified randomisation of DMAs or US States.

2. Pretest and experiment time periods

  • The pretest period is used to match similar markets, or prepare a stratified random sampling of geos to come up with the Control and Treatment geo groups.
  • During the experiment time period, we make the change we want to test (e.g. increased ad-spend, or turning off of media spend) in the Treatment geos.
  • Once the experiment has ended, we can reset everything to their original state while we analyse the results.
  • Some methods also use a cooldown time period this is when everything is back to their original state and the data from this period is also included in the analysis to account for lagged effects.

3. Analysis of results

  • A regression model is trained using data from the pretest period to estimate parameters and their uncertainty.
  • This model is then used to predict the counterfactual behavior of the treatment group during the test period for each time period in the test phase.
  • This helps us understand what the Treatment group would have behaved like had it not been intervened on.
    • The difference between its actual behavior (observation) and the prediction on its expected behavior (the counterfactual) is the incrementality we are after.

Time Based Regression results. 1. First plot shows Observed number of purchases in the Treatment group vs Predicted number of purchases in the Treatment group. Prediction here is an answer to the question: How many purchases would we have had if there had been no ad spend?  2. Second plot shows the pointwise differences between Observed and Predicted those are our incremental purchases for the day. 3. Third plot shows cumulative incremental purchases ending at around ~170 mark concluding that we had ~170 incremental purchases due to the campaign.

There are two methods we can rely on for analysis: Time Based Regression (TBR) and Geo Based Regression. TBR predicts the time series of the counterfactual market response, allowing for direct estimation of the cumulative causal effect at the end of the experiment.

A GBR experiment is designed in the exact same manner, except during the analysis period it uses a simple linear regression to predict the counterfactual response. Since GBR produced many false positives in internal evaluations, we generally would not rely on GBR. [2]

Geo experiment metrics

For our internal analyses, we look at the following metrics for each experiment: Registrations, Signups, New Purchases, and Revenue. We defined these metrics here and rely on Ad Tracking definitions as developed by MarTech.

Background reading material

Measuring Ad Effectiveness Using Geo Experiments

Estimating Ad Effectiveness using Geo Experiments in a Time-Based Regression Framework

Geo Experiments Part 1: What Is It and How Will It Help You In Marketing?

Coming up

  • Marketers checklist to setting up and running a geo experiment
  • Data scientists workflow tosetting upandanalysing a geo experiment
  • Introduction toGeoX, our internal Geo Experiment framework for Automattic
  • Interpreting geo experiment results

1. The internal a8c GeoX framework now supports any geocountrycode and geocountryregion based splits we have in tracks.prod_events such as France split into cities, or US split into States along with DMA-based splits though they are problematic.

2. TBR aggregates data at the date-and-geo level, whereas GBR aggregates data at the geo level only. GBR aggregates data first at the experiment start date then at the experiment end date making it slightly more robust against seasonal changes that may hit the Control and Treatment geos differently but resulting in a less sophisticated and flexible methodology.

item.title: Portfolio
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Some examples of things I can help you with. Also, the answer to the question "What do you do all day"?

I have used the below tools and tactics, among others, to achieve hyper-growth for my clients, multiply their ROI, increase their profitability and achieve their growth and marketing goals.

For every section below you will find a sample list of business questions and problems I have helped my clients answer and solve to help grow their business.

You will also find examples of dashboards and analyses I use to answer these questions. My work is data-driven and I use insights to help companies achieve growth.

[ez-toc]

Channel Optimization

PPC

PPC Optimal Bids

What is the optimal bid for our campaigns and what bid adjustments should we make?

Google Ads Day and Time Optimizations

What is the optimal day and time to run Google Ads in order to optimize performance?

Google Ads Impression Share

What is our impressions share for Google Ads? Are we losing conversions because we are not ranking or not optimizing our budget?

Google Ads Campaign Automation

What is the percentage of automation in our Google Ads campaigns and how can we improve it?

Google Ads Creative Optimization

Google Ads Creative optimization: which ad types perform better and how can we optimize them?

Resources:

  • Google Ads Bid Adjustments
  • Google Ads Time and Day Optimization
  • Google Ads Impression Share
  • Google Ads Campaign Automation
  • Google Ads Creative Performance Insights

SEO

Trending Queries

What queries are trending right now so we can capitalize on them?

Questions that users are asking (for content ideation)

What questions are people asking that are relevant to our website? Can we write content to answer these questions?

Landing pages cannibalization

Are we cannibalizing our landing pages with multiple queries?

Share of Search

What is our share of search compared to competitors?

Image Search

Can we capitalize on image search? What images can bring traffic to the website?

Resources:

  • Google Search Console Dashboard
  • Share of Search Report
  • Keyword Cannibalization Dashboard

Google Updates impact on SEO

What is the impact of Google Updates on our SEO performance?

Paid Social

Optimal Frequency for Ads

What is the optimal frequency for our ads in order to avoid ad fatigue?

Audience Saturation

Are we saturating our audiences? What is the percentage of new people that we're reaching?

How should we allocate our budget?

Cost Curves/Diminishing Returns

What is the relationship between our spend and conversions and what is the point of diminishing returns?

Marginal CPA

What is the marginal CPA (i.e. how much more are we paying for an extra conversions) for each level of spend?

Budget Optimizer

How should I allocate my budget between paid channels?

Try out the app I made to allocate budget optimally based on cost curves for marketing channels.

Resources:

  • Example Marginal CPA and Cost Curve report
  • Budget Optimizer App

What is the incremental return of channel/campaign X?

Causal Inference Test/Analysis

How do I measure the incrementality of a TV campaign? How do I measure incrementality if I can't run a proper experiment?

GeoLift Test

Can I measure the incrementality of a channel or campaign by splitting the test and control group by geographical area?

Check out the Apps I have made for GeoLift Power Analysis (i.e. which markets should I select for my test, for how long and with what budget?) and Geolift Post-Test Analysis (i.e what was the incrementality of the test vs the control group).

Incrementality/Lift Test

How can we measure the incrementality of a digital channel (conversion lift)?

Resources:

  • Google's Causal Impact for Causal Inference (GitHub)
  • Meta's GeoLift for running incrementality experiments with test and control in different regions (GitHub)

Forecasting

Forecast App

Use the app below to forecast your conversions or other metrics that are important to your business. The app is based on Meta Prophet and uses trend, holidays and seasonality to forecast the metric.

Try out the Forecast app here.

CPM Price Forecast based on seasonality

Can we forecast CPM prices based on seasonality?

Resources:

  • Using Meta's Prophet to forecast CPM prices (GitHub)

Attribution and Marketing Mix Modeling

Marketing Mix Model

What is the incremental contribution of each channel? How can we improve our attribution given the limitations of iOS14?

Attribution Models

How can we improve our attribution?

Resources:

  • An MMM using Meta Robyn (GitHub)
  • An MMM using Google's Lightweight MMM (GitHub)
  • Case Study: How I created a custom attribution model for NA-KD and improved their ROI (8X incremental return on ad spend for new customers, 5X incremental return on ad spend for all customers)
  • Guide: How to create your own data-driven custom attribution model
  • Creating different attribution models with Conversion Path data (GitHub)

Retention, LTV, Churn, Lead Generation

LTV, Retention, Churn

LTV Calculation/Cohort Analysis

What is the LTV of our clients?

Aha Moment

What is the Aha Moment of our users?

Resources:

  • Cohort analysis for LTV prediction (GitHub)

Lead Quality and others

Lead Quality Scoring/Lead Pipeline Analysis

What is the quality of a lead based on the data we have at the time of the lead generation? How can we help the sales team select the highest quality leads and increase the lead quality?

Sentiment Analysis

What is the emotional tone associated to the online reviews of our product?

Example sentiment analysis of online reviews (GitHub)

Pricing Analysis

What is the optimal price for our product?

  • GitHub code for Van Westendorp Price Sensitivity Analysis

item.title: raft
item.dc:creator: christosvis

item.title: [draft] A framework for Growth Analytics: from Descriptive to Predictive and Prescriptive Analytics
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Working as a Marketing Analytics consultant, a problem that I often encountered with my clients was that their Analytics only focused on the past.

My goal was to incorporate not just descriptive but also prescriptive and predictive analytics into our work.

  • Descriptive analytics refers to what happened in the past and is the usual post-campaign analysis.
  • Predictive analytics tries to predict what will happen in the future.
  • Prescriptive analytics provides recommendations in order to make better decisions for those future outcomes.

The different types live together and feed each other as described below.

  • Post- campaign is the analytics that usually occurs the most, where we try to see what happened in the past (descriptive analytics). This is very valuable and it depends on the right selection of KPIs and goals to understand if our marketing activities were successful or not. This type of analysis feeds all the other types with data and meta-analysis. Examples of Post-campaign include the dashboards and reports we use for regular reporting, but also the experiments we run to gather insights and the custom analyses we do to investigate why something happened.
  • Pre-campaign usually consists of small tests to assess ad elements (e.g. creatives) and checklists of campaign elements (e.g. reach, frequency, ad formats, audiences) based on meta-analyses and experiments done in the Post-campaign cluster. Essentially, the goal is to produce a campaign recipe book (prescriptive analytics). For example, if campaign X targets country A, with frequency B, reach C, on platform/ad format D, then we expect a range of Z-Y for its main KPI. The more we feed Pre-campaign with Post-campaign data points and analyses, the more accurate we expect this to be.
  • In-flight analytics is a series of decision tress to help us manage campaigns while they are running. Our goal is to compare campaign KPIs while running to benchmarks based on our Post-campaign analyses, but also based on the results we predicted on Pre-campaign. We want to define actions based on those benchmarks (e.g. if KPI A < X then pause campaign etc). Essentially, the better a job we do on Pre and Post-campaign the less need for intervention in the In-flight period.
  • Future is the predictive analytics part, where we try to understand what will happen in the mid to long-term and apply statistical models to help us make better decisions. Econometric models, Cross-media incrementality, and other types of models will enable us to answer questions such as: What should our marketing budget allocation be for the next quarter/half/year?, How many conversions and sales should we expect from Channel A? etc.

Obviously, the goal of this framework is to help us make better decisions and the feedback loops in it are meant to act as assessment mechanisms (did we predict outcomes correctly?) and also feed our analyses/models with more data in order to make them more accurate.

item.title: How to Create Your Own Custom Attribution Model
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Allocating marketing budget efficiently is problematic without knowing the contribution of each marketing channel to a users lifetime value and your overall conversions. 

The problem arises from the fact that analytics tools and marketing tools report thelast clickthat occurred and are biased towardstheir own data. Plus, they cant always detect other channels efficiently.

As companies and marketing budgets grow, customer journeys become more complex and convoluted since the number of marketing channels they use increases.

Heres an example. Lets think about a conversion path in which a user first interacts with a Facebook ad, then performs a Google search for the product and finally opens the companys newsletter before converting. 

In this case, the same conversion would be reported differently in different tools. 

  • Facebook would get credit in Facebook Ads Manager, and yet
  • Google would get credit as the last paid channel inGoogle Analytics.

As seen in the example above, relying on third-party tools for attribution will not reveal the whole customer journey and will have inherent biases because of the data and the way it is treated under different analytics tools.

Create your own attribution model

The goal is to create your own custom attribution model. This way you can give credit where credit is due when it comes to the different channels on your customer journey. 

Having a data-driven model helps you to: 

  • Allocate your budget to the most effective channels
  • Target the most valuable users based on their lifetime value.

Collect data for your attribution model

In order to create an attribution model you need all the customer paths (converting and non-converting) that occurred on your website / app.

A path consists of the touchpoints (clicks) that the user interacted with during a typical conversion window.

Touchpoints are captured through the UTM tags used in your campaigns. 

Capturing UTM Tags

UTM tags are parameters appended in the URLs of marketing campaigns that do not modify the destination of the URL but pass on information that can be captured by analytics tools. 

For example, a URL from a Facebook campaigns would look like this:

https://www.example.com/
?utm_source=facebook
&utm_medium=social
&utm_campaign=nameofyourcampaign

This URL directs people to example.com. Everything after the ? is not part of the web address but passes on parameters to identify information for the origin source of the traffic. These parameters fire when the above URL is loaded. 

The parameters used to identify the sources of traffic are:

  • utm_source:The channel that brought the traffic (e.g. Google, Facebook etc)
  • utm_medium: The type of traffic (e.g. social, paid search etc)
  • utm_campaign: the name of the campaign

Note that you can manually choose the UTM tags for your campaigns, but you can also assign them dynamically. For example, this article shows you how to use dynamic UTM tagging for your Facebook campaigns. 

If you dont use UTM tags for your campaigns, the analytics tools that you use will capture the URL of the referrer but will label it as organic instead of paid.

Capturing user level data

The second thing to consider is user-level data, i.e. the ability to identify users by assigning a unique ID to them if possible. In that case, youll be able to have a proper cross-channel and cross-device attribution and not rely just on cookies.

Analytics tools like Mixpanel or Heap give you the ability to identify device IDs and user IDs, and use the combination of the above dimensions to identify multiple devices for each user across the customer journey.

Capturing conversion & revenue data

Since the attribution model data consists of the converting and non-converting paths of your users, along with the touchpoints that you will get from the UTM tags, you will also need the conversions and the respective value (revenue) for those conversions, likely found in your CRM.

These data points will help you calculate the conversions, revenue and ROI for each marketing channel.

Pull all your data together

In order to create your own custom attribution model without relying on the attribution models your analytics tools provide, you will need to import all the data we described above into one place, ideally a database or data warehouse.

An easy and efficient way to do this is to use an ETL tool which enables you to connect all your marketing data in minutes, saving massive amounts of time and developer resources. 

Once you have all the metrics and dimensions required for the attribution model imported into your database, you should consider a few factors for your model.

Decide on an attribution window

Decide on an attribution window based on your data and business considerations like the purchase cycle for your products. The attribution window is the time period during which a purchase should be credited to a touchpoint that happened within that period. 

Different industries have different purchase cycles and that affects their attribution window. 

For example, it takes much longer for a customer to decide on the purchase of a vacation package worth thousands of dollars than to buy an inexpensive t-shirt. Generally, expensive purchases have long cycles that might take months and dozens of touchpoints to complete, whereas cheaper and impulse purchases might take only a few hours from the first touchpoint to the conversion.

Analytics tools like Google Analytics provide reports that help you see the distribution of users based on how long it took them in terms of time and number of touchpoints to convert.

Building your Attribution Model

There are two widely accepted data-driven models for attribution: 

  1. Shapley Value
  2. Markov Chains.

The inputs needed for both models are the touchpoints and the conversions, which as stated above are part of the data that you will import into your database.

Using the Shapley Value Attribution Model

Shapley Value - named after the Nobel Prize-winning economist Lloyd Shapley - is a game theory model for cooperative problems. In other words, the model tries to assign credit to different parties that contributed to a total value. This is also the question were trying to answer with an attribution model, namely how much credit every marketing channel should get for making a user convert along the path.

The Shapley model is also the one used by Google for their own data-driven attribution model in Google Analytics 360, however by creating your own model you will have better control over your data and will avoid the biases that Google Analytics might have by giving more credit to Google Search.

In order to calculate the contribution of a channel under the Shapley Value model, we compare all the different permutations of paths and touchpoints that occurred. For example, we take two paths that differ by a single touchpoint and we assign the difference in total value to that extra touchpoint, since it is the only difference between the two.

Then we compute all the permutations and we assign credit to each channel accordingly. Thus, the model calculates the probability of conversion when a specific channel is present in the conversion path.

Using the Markov Chain Attribution Model

The Markov Chain model - named after the Russian mathematician Andrey Markov - describes the sequence of various events and tries to make predictions based on them. Once again, we try to assign the probability of a user converting when exposed to various marketing channels.

The Markov Chain model assigns credit to marketing channels by calculating the removal effect. The removal effect depicts what happens when we remove a marketing channel from a path and see how many conversions take place without that channel.

By calculating all the different permutations of paths and the removal effects for every touchpoint, we end up with a probability to convert for each marketing channel.

In both the Shapley and the Markov model, the output is a matrix of all marketing channels and a probability or credit for all conversions that occur thanks to each of those channels.

The above table is an example of the output of a custom attribution model compared to a standard last-click model. Note that the total number of conversions is the same for both models, but what changes is the allocation between different channels. Moreover, the data-driven model can have fractional conversions, since credit for a conversion is given to multiple channels.

You can also calculate the revenue and ROI for each of the channels since you have conversions, revenue and marketing cost in your database. This will help you allocate your marketing budget across channels.

How to run a Lift Test
