In the models and data mentioned above we talked about capturing touchpoints via UTM tags. UTM tags occur through clicks, which means that there are channels (mainly social media) that will be underrepresented due to the lack of impressions.

In order to incorporate impressions to your model, you should consider running lift tests for channels like Facebook and Instagram as they rely on impressions more than other channels. 

A lift test is a randomized control test where we randomize an audience into a test and control group. We only show ads to the test group. 

The difference in conversions between the two groups is known as lift or incrementality and represents the real impact of a channels ads on the audience. Moreover, since this is based on the concept of randomized control trials, it also incorporates the concept of causality, meaning that we know that it was the ads that caused the extra conversions.

A good practice is to regularly run lift tests (e.g. once a quarter) so that you can see the effect of Facebook, Instagram and other impression-heavy channels and calibrate your attribution model accordingly.

Lift test vs attribution model

Both attribution models and lift tests are useful and should work in conjunction to give the best possible results. They both have their advantages and limitations, as you can see in the table below:

Incorporating Offline Activities into your attribution model with Matched Market Tests

For offline activities (TV, billboards etc) it is recommended to run Matched Market Tests, where you take two similar geographic areas and use them as a test and control group to get results. The calculation of results is similar to a lift test but we have to acknowledge that this is not a perfect test, as the audiences are not randomized. 

You can also employ before-after tests, where you compare two periods of time with different marketing activities. 

Something we have to take into account when running all sorts of tests is duration and seasonality. 

A rule of thumb is that tests should last for at least one week (and ideally 4 weeks or more), since there might be fluctuations of conversions for different days (e.g. a lot more conversions on weekends compared to weekdays). Moreover, you should avoid periods during which you experience big increases or decreases (e.g. Christmas, Black Friday).

item.title: How I created a custom attribution model for NA-KD and improved their ROI (Facebook Case Study)
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
I have outlined in one of my posts how to create a custom attribution model using your own data and not relying on third party tools, where the attribution model is a black box.

When I was working at Facebook as Marketing Science Partner, attribution was one of the most pressing issues for our clients, and I actually published the first case study globally for attribution at Facebook.

The problem

My client, NA-KD, a Swedish fashion ecommerce company and one of the fastest growing companies in Europe, was increasing and diversifying its marketing budget to enhance its growth. The problem was that because they were advertising on multiple channels (Facebook, Google, affiliates, email etc) each channel would report its own figures which made reporting for the whole marketing mix confusing and allocating budget very hard.

Moreover, as a fashion company, they had a lot of ads and content that generated millions of impressions, especially on visual mediums like Instagram and, also, collaborated with influencers. These activities usually are not reported on tools like Google Analytics - which they were using - with a standard last-touch attribution model in place.

The solution

I worked with NA-KDs analytics team, used data from multiple sources including Google Analytics and Facebook and created buckets of marketing activities (e.g. prospecting, retargeting) and assigned weights to them by analyzing conversion paths.

I then designed a new data-driven attribution model based on Shapley Value to reflect the contribution of each channel/activity more accurately.

The model worked well but had one gap: the fact that the data we were using was mainly click data. In order to incorporate impressions to our model, I ran a series of conversion lift tests to identify the incremental impact of impressions and Facebook/Instagram (which was the main channel relying on impressions).

The results

As you can see in the published case study, the results were impressive: using the new attribution model, NA-KD saw an 8X incremental return on ad spend for new customers, 5X incremental return on ad spend for all customers, and was able to measure the true impact of Facebook ads which was heavily undervalued by using the old last-touch model.

Moreover, my work didnt stop there: I designed a plan to run lift tests on a regular basis, in order to calibrate the model every few months and make sure that decision-making is optimized.

item.title: How I helped Unisport increase their sales with segmentation analysis
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
One of the most powerful tools that an analyst has at their disposal is segmentation analysis, which can help you uncover opportunities that you wouldn't notice otherwise.

Here's an example of how I helped my client Unisport (a soccer apparel and equipment company) increase their sales, while I was working at Facebook. The tool I used? Segmentation analysis!

How I did it

Unisport, one of my clients at Facebook, is a company that sells sports equipment and wanted to get more conversions. 

I did a segmentation analysis that revealed that there were two major demographic groups that were existing or potential customers: young males (which the company was already targeting) and females in their 30s-50s (which the company didn't pay attention to). The women were most likely mothers that wanted to buy soccer shoes for their children.

I worked with the client's marketing team and we developed two separate marketing campaigns for the two demographics.

The one that targeted young men focused on the new flashy shoes that are associated with the star athletes.

The other one spoke to mothers by focusing on inexpensive, safe shoes and equipment for their children. We also did a "Back to School" campaign to link it to this demographic.

The company managed to increase their conversions multiple times while seeing a very good CPA for both groups of users.

item.title: How to use Facebook Lead Ads to generate quality low-cost leads (a Zopto case study)
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
If you're a B2B company, Lead Ads should be your primary campaign objective on Facebook.

As a matter of fact, this is how I helped my B2B client Zopto to grow on Facebook by lowering their cost per lead 5X, converting more leads and automating their marketing activity to scale it.

How I did it

Zopto was getting lots of leads on Facebook but they werent high quality (low conversion rate) and they had a high cost.

I changed their campaign structure simplifying it, relying on custom audiences (CRM data) and lookalikes to get more relevant customers.

I also A/B tested copy and creative, and found out that videos that showcased the service performed better than other creatives.

Moreover, I simplified the lead generation for the user: instead of directing them to the website and having them perform lots of clicks, I had them fill in a lead form on Facebook which required very little effort from them and optimized it on mobile, as most people use Facebook on mobile (in contrast to the website form which wasnt optimized for mobile).

That lowered the cost per lead significantly and generated better leads. What is more, I utilized Hubspot to automate email marketing workflows and help convert people who had already signed up for a demo of the software.

All in all, Zopto scaled on Facebook and combined it with email and other activities to grow their business, thanks to this optimization strategy.

item.title: [draft] Getting Our Moneys Worth: Using Cost Curves To Optimize PaidAcquisition
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
We spend quite a lot of money to acquire users via SEM and other paid channels. Traditionally weve used ROAS (return on ad spend) as the metric to optimize for. As this post will show, that approach does not actually optimize for Automattics profit but for the profit of whoever is selling us the ads (Google, Facebook, ). This might be fine if we wanted to optimize for brand exposure and free accounts, but if we want to optimize for running a lean and mean marketing machine we should prioritize our own profit. 

To address this discrepancy, we are working on an algorithm that takes in data from previous bids on ads and then uses cost curves (see below) to find the optimal bidding strategy. This will then allow us to adjust our bids to maximize profits, leading to more efficient paid acquisition. 

The solution were building involves the following steps: 

  1. Make bids to gather data on how marginal ROAS behaves at different price points. 
  2. Analyze the data from those bids to build cost curves that let us find the optimal bidding strategy. 
  3. Adjust our bids to use the profit-maximizing strategy. 

For a cupcake MVP, we only need to get step 2 to work reliably and automatically steps 1 and 3 can be manual for now (currently done by @heyjonthego  thank you ). If we find that the benefit of this approach warrants the investment, we can iterate on our solution and automate steps 1 and / or 3 as well. For now, @davidafishman has sketched a first solution using bidding data exported to a Google Sheet, which is then consumed by an iPython notebook running on Google Colab. Wed like to take it to the next step to make it more reliable, usable, and to run it on our own infrastructure. 

Cost Curves

Cost curves can allow growth marketers make better decisions as they allow offer a framework for:

  • Optimal bidding within a channel
  • Allocation of budget across channels
  • Forecast with improved precision
  • Avoid operating with averages and instead at the margin 

Cost Curves describe the tradeoff between media cost and marketing return.  Typically in paid advertising as cost increases the rate of return decreases.  This can turn into a plot that might look something similar to the chart below.  

Example of a Cost Curve Experiment

Imagine an online business that sells an e-book. There are no real cost for selling the e-book besides marketing costs. Below is a table that shows how much revenue our company brought in by week as our company slowly increased ad spend on Google once a week.

Revenue does appear to be slowing as cost is increasing, but it is a bit unclear from the table what exact ROAS the business should target  Since the business  is a profit seeking business, the business needs to not maximize Googles profit, but instead maximize its own profit. The business needs to figure out what exact ROAS to target to maximize profit.

By adding in profit it becomes clearer that as spend increases the profit also starts to increase. Then, as ad spend continues to increase beyond a certain point, profit starts to decrease. 

There seems to be a point of profit maximization somewhere! It is interesting to note that running until ROAS is 100% in this business will maximize Googles profit and ensure that the business has no economic profit.

Marginal Analysis 

In microeconomics, profit is maximized when marginal cost is equal to marginal revenue. To maximize our profits, a business would continue to invest when Marginal ROAS is above 100% and pull back media spend when Marginal ROAS is less than 100% (change in revenue divided by change in cost). 

The table below approximates the marginal revenue and margin cost by examining the differences between cost or revenue as cost increases For example, at a cost of $100,000 the marginal ROAS is 141%.  Since marginal ROAS is above 100% there should be a further increase in media investment.

As spend goes from $200,000 to $300,000, additional revenue only increases by $56,401 ($585,087-$528,686) yielding a marginal roas of 56% ($56,401/$100,000).  Since this marginal ROAS is less than 100% it is clear that the business should not invest beyond $200,000. This is validated by the profit column which shows profit shrinking from $328,686 to $285,087.  

While the table is useful in helping us determine general investment decisions, it does not yield the desired precision to extend the table to other areas of investment such as $25,000 or $400,000 of ad spend. It is also unclear how to predict spend at $75,000 as a midpoint solution does not take into account decreasing marginal returns.

Fitting a curve to the data would allow one to predict at any level of spend and find optimal points based on business objectives.

It is possible to plot the cost and revenue points and then fit a curve to our data.  This visual approach clearly shows that as ad spend is increasing, revenue is really slowing down. At extreme levels of spend, the cost curve starts to flatten: for each additional dollar of advertising cost the revenue will hardly grow.

This same curve can be transformed to plot profit instead of revenue. This allows us to visually identify the point of profit maximization and to understand the relationship between cost and ad spend.

Marginal ROAS can also be plotted. When marginal ROAS is equal to 100% (marginal revenue / marginal cost) profit will be maximized.

Allocation Decisions

Cost curves help determine how to logically think about advertising and the concept can easily be extended to allocate a budget to different media channels.

Scenario

Imagine two channels: Facebook and Google. Both are operating at exactly the same ROAS of 250% with $100,000 of cost and $250,000 of revenue. OurCMO comes to MarTech and asks how to best invest additional marketing dollars.

Looking at traditional metrics such as revenue per click, conversion rate, click through rate, and pretty much anything else would not help determine how to best invest the extra marketing dollars. 

Cost curves should be used to better help us understand the true marginal return of the next dollar of ad spend.  

By using a cost curve and looking at marginal returns, we can see that investing in Facebook marketing would be a better decision than investing in Google marketing. An investment in Facebook would bring in $1.24 of revenue for each dollar of cost invested, while an investment in Google will only bring in $0.50 for each additional dollar. 

Conclusion

Cost curves are a powerful tool for optimizing ad spend for our own profit.has a proof of concept running on Google Colab, using a manually exported Google Sheet as its data source.

Wed now like to take it to the next level by making it more reliable, versatile, usable, and to have it run on our own infrastructure. Once achieved, we can think about investing in automating additional steps of the process. 

An important point not yet addressed is that this approach needs to buy ads to gather data points for building cost curves. Theres a spectrum between having no data but also spending no money at all, and having perfect data but paying a lot for it. 

Theres probably a sweet spot on that curve as well, and as such poses another optimization problem that well need to explore in our work. For now, wed default to a conservative and cautious approach here. 

With this post we wanted to share the technical details as well as our motivation, open questions, and possible directions to take this in.

item.title: [draft] Predicting Marketing Performance from Early Attribution Indicators
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
DoorDash uses machine learning to determine where best to spend its advertising dollars, but a rapidly changing market combined with frequent delays in data collection hampered our optimization efforts. Our new attribution forecast model lets us predict the efficacy of ad campaigns from their initial data, helping make critical business decisions earlier.

Usually, we need to wait some time to measure ad performance due to our attribution methodology. This slow reaction time means that if one ad channel performs particularly well, we cannot move our marketing dollars to that channel quickly. 

Our new attribution forecast model predicts an ads final conversion volume after observing only its initial data. This allows us to utilize more recent data, optimizing our conversions per ad spend by scaling the best channels as performance changes over time.

Beyond routine optimization, this forecasting framework is especially useful during marketing experimentswhere identifying the winning ad sooner accelerates impactand could be extended to other delayed-information problems, such as ticket sales for concerts, hotel bookings, or holiday flower sales. 

Intro to attribution methodology

Before we talk about the forecast model, lets discuss what an attribution system is and how to choose one. An attribution system helps companies measure the effectiveness of marketing campaigns. It has two key elements: allocation method and attribution window.

Reviewing allocation methods

The allocation method determines how to assign credit across marketing touchpoints when a new consumer places their first order, commonly called conversion. Allocation methods can be either single touch or multi-touch, depending on the number of channels that get credit for the conversion. See Figure 1 for an illustration.

  • Single touch assigns all conversion credit to a single channel, assuming that either the first or last touchpoint drives the conversion.
  • Multi-touch considers all touchpoints along the path to conversion. As a simple example, it might distribute credit to all touchpoints evenly.

Trade-off in attribution windows

Intuitively, the impact of marketing isnt always immediate. After the customer in the example above saw the DoorDash commercial on TV, they might have taken days or even a few weeks before placing their first order. Thus, another key question in attribution methodology is how many days to look back when defining marketing touchpoints. This time period is the attribution window.

A long attribution window allows companies to recognize more conversions for any given ad. Figure 2, below, shows the difference in cost curve between two attribution windows. With a shorter attribution window (the seven-day attribution below in red), the new customers who converted after seven days arent credited to the ad, leading to a cost curve that underestimates the ad efficiency.

At the same time, conversion patterns are different across ads. For example, some ads, such as those on search channels, lead to a quick conversion, while ads on other channels, such as TV or radio, are slower. A shorter attribution window will cause us to underestimate the attribution for slower ads more, resulting in suboptimal marketing decisions.

However, too long of an attribution window is also undesirable because it requires a longer wait time to fully measure an ads performance. In a rapidly changing market, longer wait times may result in out-of-date cost curves. If we could somehow include this data that isnt available yet, the extra information would materially improve our cost curves and in turn marketing decisions, as shown in Figure 3:

The problem with our legacy attribution system

Currently, DoorDash uses a several-day last-touch attribution system for all digital marketing channels, which provides a good balance between a holistic view of conversions for most ads, and reasonable wait time for fully refreshed attribution performance. 

However, an attribution window of several days still means that ads posted in the last few days are operating off of incomplete attribution data, which cant inform marketing decisions until the window has elapsed. Given the rapid changes in the food delivery marketing landscape, having to wait before reacting to recent data isnt ideal. We needed a way to unlock our most recent data.

Forecasting final outcomes

Before we jump into the details, lets discuss an ideal solution. Our ad channels come in different shapes and sizes. For example, we run a small number of high-spend TV ads and a huge number of low-spend search ads (sometimes targeting individual obscure keywords, like misspellings of DoorDash). Ideally, our solution should handle both small and large ads.

The approach we chose was to build a forecasting model that predicts final attribution data from a limited amount of initial data.

Defining forecast accuracy

An easy way to measure the performance of our forecast model is by backtesting. Backtesting means training the model on old data and checking whether it can predict more recent data.

The main performance metric we picked is mean absolute error (MAE), 

where ci is conversions attributed to ad i and the hat ^ distinguishes a prediction from the actual value. Because MAE simply takes the absolute value of forecasting errors, it isnt biased toward larger ads (unlike root mean square error, RMSE) or smaller ones (unlike mean absolute percentage error, MAPE).

However, one pitfall of MAE is it scales with conversion volume, which makes it harder to compare across channels or other segments, such as day of week. To facilitate comparison, we normalized MAE by conversion volume:

Building the forecast model

We wanted a forecast model that updates its predictions as we collect more data. It should be able to predict the final attribution outcome, whether there are four days of observations to work with or ten. The more of this initial data the model has, the more accurate the forecast should be.

We evaluated two types of models: 

  • Simple heuristic models 
  • Machine learning models

Simple heuristic models

The simplest models we considered assume the conversion pattern for an ad will be the same in the future as the past N weeks. For example, suppose we want to predict the number of conversions attributed to an ad at the end of a 30 day window, c(30 d). The prediction on day t (tth day after the ad is posted) is

where c(t) is the number of attributed conversions observed so far. This approach directly applies a historical ratio to predict final conversions from the current observation.

Below are some of the parameters or variations we explored with this heuristic model. We selected the best parameterized model by backtesting, as described in the previous section.

  • Number of weeks N used to calculate historical conversion ratio. This parameter corresponds to the question of how long the conversion pattern stays the same: too long (larger N) might be slow to capture market changes, while too short (smaller N) might be noisy. We considered values from one to twelve weeks.
  • Aggregation. Related to the previous point, small ads might generate too little data to confidently calculate the historical conversion ratio. Aggregating similar (e.g., same channel, creative, or region) ads when calculating the ratio can decrease noise.
  • Seasonality adjustments. Seasonality, especially day of week, plays an important role in our new customer conversions. For example, a consumer is more likely to place their first order on a weekend night than a Tuesday night. To account for that, we could  calculate a different historical ratio for each day of the week.

Machine learning models

This forecast is a typical regression problem. We tested the following machine learning regression methods:

Results

As shown in Figure 4, below, the LightGBM and simple heuristic models significantly outperform the other models.

However, how would this accuracy improvement translate to better marketing decisions? To better understand the true impact, we plugged the forecast model predictions back into our downstream workflow and used them to draw cost curves. Figure 5, below, shows that when these predictions are included, an example ads cost curve captures spend efficiency more accurately, which in turn helps us assign our marketing budget more optimally. In this case, without the forecast predictions we would underestimate the ads performance and mistakenly move some of its budget to other channels.

As with forecast accuracy, we backtested cost curve accuracy using the same approach and the same normalized MAE metric. Currently, the cost curves are able to achieve a reasonable normalized MAE with delayed historical data, as shown in Figure 6. By plugging in the forecast predictions, the best models (simple heuristic and LightGBM) further decrease the error significantly.

In conclusion, by taking advantage of recent data more quickly, the attribution forecast model significantly enhances our ability to draw cost curves and make marketing decisions. We found that the heuristic and LightGBM models performed similarly, so we chose to productionize the heuristic model because its simpler and more interpretable.

Summary and next steps

At this point one might ask, why does the simplest model perform best? We think there are two reasons:

  • Strong existing patterns: Consumer conversions after a marketing touchpoint usually follow a particular pattern. The majority of consumers are going to convert in the first few days, and the number gradually reduces. External factors play a relatively small role in impacting consumer behavior when the onboarding funnel is short. Therefore, a simple heuristic adequately captures the conversion flow.
  • Limited amount of data: Typically, we have only several days of observations on which to base a forecast prediction. With this small amount of data, more complex ML models dont show many advantages. 

When patterns are less obvious, or the ads of interest span a hierarchy of different regions or countries, a simple heuristic might not perform as well and a more advanced model might be justified.

A similar methodology could be applied to attribution systems at other companies. Depending on the data available, an easy model like the simple heuristic could be a great place to start. Beyond marketing attribution, applications could also include other delayed-response situations. For example, predicting final concert ticket volume from the first few days of sales, or predicting final hotel occupancy on any given day from early bookings. Learning the final outcome sooner enables faster reactions and better decisions.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Predicting Marketing Performance from Early Attribution Indicators
Predicting Marketing Performance from Early Attribution Indicators

item.title: [draft] Marketer's Guide to Running Geo Experiments
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Geo experiments help determine incrementality and lift in settings where it is difficult to target and segment at the user-level. They are mainly used in asserting efficiency of ad campaigns. Geo experiments rely on complicated statistical heavy lifting in the background. This means that certain checks need to be done before starting an experiment, and rules need to be adhered to while running an experiment. Not every set up will be testable, the data scientist you are working with will do the checks on your proposed setup to ensure that the experiment will have results and is worth running.

Caution: One of the biggest mistakes you can make when setting up or analysing a geo experiment is thinking of it as a simple A/B test. There is no comparison of before-and-after or a "simple comparison" of rates of increase in a given metric in the Control vs Treatment groups in geo experiments. This is because simple A/B test methods rely on randomisation at the user level whereas geo experiments predict the counterfactual.

It is easy to fall prey the famous garbage-in-garbage-out issue when it comes to geo experiments, unfortunately, as these analyses take careful consideration. This mainly happens when geo experiments are mistook for a simple A/B test and we try to compare rates of change in a Treatment group to a Control group. Those results are not actually usable even if they "look" significant and pass significance tests designed for simple A/B tests.

However, if you are reading this guide, that means you are working with a data scientist to correctly set up and analyse a geo experiment. This is a list of things you need to consider and do as a non-datum when setting up a geo experiment.

Information you must provide

There are three periods to an experiment:

  • Pre-test: This is when you design an experiment and get it reviewed. At the end of this period you will receive a file from the data scientist that shows which geos should be targeted in which campaigns.
  • Experiment: This is the period when your campaigns are running. Will take about 6-8 weeks.
  • Experiment end: This begins after you have ended the experiment and campaigns. You should receive results almost immediately.
    • Cooldown period: You can re-run the analysis 2 weeks after experiment end to get a new report that accounts for lagged purchases/signups/registrations.

You should run through the entire guide and provide all information. The following items will be fed into the analysis system:

  1. Pre-test: Geo Strategy
    • Experiment to be run for US States.
  2. Pre-test: Objective Metric
    • Interested in impact in signups.
  3. Pre-test: Number of cells for the experiment
    • We need 4 cells: Facebook, Google, Facebook + Google, Control
  4. Experiment end: Launch date
  5. Experiment end: Experiment end date
  6. Experiment end: Budget spent in each cell

Read the guide for further details.

Pre-test period checklist

  1. P2 threads - Create a post on a8cexperiments.wordpress.com.
    • Title of the post should start with GeoX which stands for Geo Experiments.
    • The 6 items from below should be included in the P2 post.
  2. Geo Strategy - State your region and its country code for the experiment.
    • Example: United States of America, US
    • If you are running the test in the US, then the results will only be applicable to the US.
    • If you specify US, then the experiment will divide US into States.
      • This is less powerful than splitting by US DMAs. However, we do not have official Nielsen DMA mappings for US and we can't target by DMA until we do.
    • If you specify a country then the experiment will divide the country into other regions, such as cities. This is the same georegion as what we see in tracks.prod_events georegion column.
    • Please specify both country and geocountrycode. Example: Hungary, HU.
  3. Objective Metric - State your primary metric.
    • Example: purchases.
    • Every geo experiment at a8c comes with an analysis for the following metrics: signups, registrations, purchases, revenue. But you still need one single primary metric.
    • If you are trying to test incrementality on a strategy that has been used before, then give as much data as you can about its previous performance.
    • Example: What is the historical CPA (cost per acquisition), ROAS (return on ad spend), and CPL (cost per lead)?
  4. Experiment Questions - State your questions.
    • Example:
    • 1. What is the incremental impact of Facebook ads on purchases in the US?
    • 2. What is the incremental impact of Google Brand SEM on purchases in the US?
    • 3. What is the combined impact of Facebook + Google on purchases in the US?


    • Number of questions determine the number of cells you will need for the experiment. If you have three questions, you will need four cells.
    • The data scientist will do a pre-analysis to ensure that results will be usable with that many cells.
    • They may come back to you and ask you to reduce the number of cells which would mean sequentialising your planned experiments by running multiple ones after each other.
    • Include a summary and links to any previous similar experiments.
  5. Group Names - Give each of your cells a name that is short and descriptive.
    • Example: If we go with the above 4-cell setup, provide the following:
    •   1: 'control',
    •   2: 'facebook',
    •   3: 'sem',
    •   4: 'facebook_sem'

  6. Experiment Name - Give your experiment a short and descriptive name and tag. Append the tag with year and month so it is easy to do further rounds.
    • Example:: Volume Squad: volume_squad_201911
  7. Hypotheses - Think about success metrics and state them.
    • How many incremental purchases do you expect to see for each cell?
    • How much lift in signups, registrations, and purchases would you consider a success for each cell?
    • What is your expected incremental CPA, ROAS, and CPL (if applicable) for each cell?
    • This does not change how the experiment is set up, it is good information to have when analysing the experiment.
  8. Contamination Risks - List any other tests that you have planned that may interfere with the results.
    • Include a summary and a link.
    • During the experiment period all other tests that may impact the results should be paused.
    • Include things like "directional testing" such as simply starting new campaigns.
    • Data scientist should review all planned interventions and determine if any need to be paused.

After posting the pretest P2

  • The data scientist will review your experiment design and make recommendations or changes.
  • The data scientist will then follow the data scientist's guide to Geo Experiments and let you know if the final setup will work or not.
  • They may ask you to consider fewer cells or a different region.
  • If all looks fine, then you will receive a Geo Assignment CSV file with the following columns: geo, variation

Experiment launch checklist

  1. P2 threads: Create a Master Thread in your team P2 for the experiment using the experiment name.
    • Link to the pre-test period P2 post from step 1 above.
    • State a launch date.
    • State an end date - give the experiment 6-8 weeks.
    • List what is required for launch.
    • State budget for each cell. Consider what uneven budgets might mean for results.
  2. Launch
    • Use the Geo Assignment CSV file to launch the campaign.
      • For each geo in the CSV, there is a corresponding `variation.
      • Launch the facebook campaign in geos where the variation is Facebook.
      • Launch the sem campaign in geos where the variation is SEM.
      • Launch the facebook_sem campaign in geos where the variation is Facebook + SEM.
      • These names depend on Group Names you came up with during the pre-test set up.
    • Launch the campaigns in each cell at the same time.
    • Make sure the launch is clean and the experiment cells are not impacted by other campaigns.
    • Set agreed upon budget for each cell.
    • Wait 6 weeks.
  3. P2 threads: Edit Master Thread to show launch information.
    • Add a comment in the Master Thread P2 post that shows the following for each cell:
      • Name and number of cell (e.g. facebook)
      • Launch date
      • Expected end date
      • Planned budget
      • Type of campaign
      • Identifier of campaign (e.g. utm_campaign parameter)

Experiment end checklist

  1. P2 threads: State end of experiment.
    • If 6-8 weeks have passed, you can likely end the experiment.
    • Ping the data scientist in the experiment Master Thread comments about wanting to end the experiment within a week.
  2. End the experiment: Revert every campaign back to normal, remove the experiment campaigns.
    • All experiment cells should come to an end at the same time.
    • State date the experiment ended in the Master Thread body post.
    • State budget spend on each cell.
    • The final information should look like this:
    • Add a comment in the Master Thread that shows the following for each cell:
      • Name of cell (e.g. facebook)
      • Launch date
      • End date
      • Spent budget
      • Type of campaign
      • Identifier of campaign (e.g. utm_campaign parameter
    • Ping the data scientist.
    • You should have results immediately.
  3. Cool-down period: Re-analyse results 2 weeks after experiment has ended.
    • 2 weeks after experiment end date, ping the data scientist.
    • The data scientist will re-run the analysis for the experiment including a cooldown period.
    • The cool-down period is an additional 2 weeks added to the analysis after the experiment is finished. It is meant to catch purchases or registrations that happened due to an ad but had a lagged impact.
  4. Reporting guide lines
    • You will receive plots, and reports that show an estimate, a lower bound, and an upper bound for each metric in each cell.
    • It will also have a column that depicts if the result is significant or not. Ignore those that are not significant.
    • For significant results, use both the estimate and the lower and upper bounds when reporting.
    • Example:The only conclusive results we see are for ~800 incremental purchases [624, 2246] and ~47K incremental cash [10.7K, 84.6K] for FB + SEM. CPA with cool-down period = 516 USD [183 USD, 788 USD]

    • Make sure the Master Thread is updated with results. You can include both cooldown and non-cooldown results.

item.title: [draft] Tales from an In-House A/B Platform
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
At my previous job, I had the privilege of leading front-end development for an A/B testing product. I thought it might be useful to share what Ive learned working on the platform.

Product Philosophy

My product manager and I spent many months grappling over the needs of inexperienced and experienced users in our experimenter community. For the inexperienced, we saw a clear need to provide more guidance and guardrails in our product; the experienced, on the other hand, essentially wanted a Spark console built into the homepage. Naturally, navigating this balance proved challenging. Whenever we made product changes favoring autonomy, we would be inundated by reports of erroneous test results due to incorrect test orchestration. Whenever we made changes removing autonomy, we would receive complaints from our most dedicated experimenters about their disrupted workflows.

It was a bit of a minefield, and we realized over time that appeasing our entire experimenter community was basically impossible. So instead, we aspired to make the best experimentation platform possible by focusing on these core product values as our guiding stars, ordered by importance:

  1. Always present correct data and analysis.
    (In other words, never present incorrect data or analyses.)
  2. Make irreversible mistakes impossible.
  3. Respect our experimenters time.

Team Composition

The A/B testing product was created, owned, and maintained by a single team solely responsible for the oversight of experiment analysis for the company. At the time of my departure, the team consisted of a product manager, a data architect, two data scientists, two backend/data engineers, and two front-end engineers. They were an amazingly bright crew.

The A/B testing product had been around for 1.5 years when I had joined the team as a lead front-end engineer. Over 9 months, I rewrote the entire user interface in React; for the remainder of my time there, I coordinated product needs with the product manager and data architect. Being situated in Silicon Valley, we were also able to collaborate with Inuits A/B team as well as Ubers experimentation team for exploring product best practices.

Core Product Features

The A/B testing product (henceforth referred to as ABP) was characterized by:

  • Centralized test variation assignment: variation assignment was centrally performed by the ABP service via an API call.
  • Centralized test management: The experimenter was able to start/stop an A/B test using the ABP interface.
  • Real-time logging verification: The experimenter was able to verify variation assignments in real-time within the ABP interface.
  • Rigidly defined set of measurable metrics: The experimenter was restricted to a fixed set of measurable metrics for collection and analysis.
  • (Mandatory usage: The experimenter was forced to use ABP for all product decisions in the company. In other words, our users were a captive audience.)

Test lifecycle management

Centralized test variation assignment was an essential characteristic of ABP that differentiates it from our current Hypotheses product. Centralizing assignment naturally gives way to centralized orchestration of A/B tests; it enables experimenters to start, stop, and update tests on the fly while leaving an audit trail for future reference. All A/B tests advanced through the following possible states:

  1. Created: The test has been initialized using the Test Builder.
    • During this state, the A/B test is assigned a unique ID and always assigns 100% of its traffic to the control group (variation A).
    • This step must be completed before any implementation can begin. Our assignment/logging API required the test ID as an input parameter.
    • The Test Builder required the experimenter to specify the following mandatory fields:
      • Test name
      • The team in charge of the test
      • Locations of the test being performed (e.g., Login)
      • Description of the tests hypothesis
      • The variation split (often 50%/50%)
      • Metrics to measure from a predefined list of metrics
  2. Started: The test has been started in the Test Details page.
    • During this state, it assigns users to the variations as defined in the Test Builder. 
    • Unfortunately, we initially allowed experimenters to change the variation split while the test was running. Doing so, however, contaminated the previously recorded data by erroneously assigning users to multiple variations. In hindsight, we should have made the variation split immutable.
    • Another flaw was borne of our lack of control over metric collection. To compensate, we derived our own set of metrics from the companys traffic/revenue tables and made them available for analysis in ABP.
    • Yet another flaw: How can an experimenter verify that the test has been correctly orchestrated in code before starting the test? While we didnt get around to completely addressing this during my time there, we built out a real-time logging verification feature for experimenters to sanity check their test orchestration. 
  3. Completed: The test has been stopped using the interface and a winner was chosen.
    • During this state, it assigns 100% of its traffic to the winning variation.
    • Enabling experimenters to end tests without deployments increased product development velocity across the company. 
    • Recording the winning variation allowed ABP to become an audit trail of product decisions. 
    • Unfortunately, this audit trail was used to establish whether a team was successful (ran many tests with experiment group winners) or underperforming (ran many tests with control group winners). 

Takeaways

While technically impressive, this A/B testing product was a product of its circumstance. This post is merely intended to inform our decisions going forward; Im certainly not advocating for centralizing test assignments nor gatekeeping a set of A/B testable metrics.Nonetheless, I believe that the core values mentioned in theProduct Philosophysectioncan be of use to us for all Data products going forward.

item.title: [draft] Test Assignment: Best Practices
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
What are the established best practices in test assignment? Does our code adhere to them? If not, then in what ways does it fail to meet the standards?

TL;DR: Were doing a few things right, but some things are not up to standard. Virtually 0% of our English speaking users experience a Vanilla WordPress.com.

Terminology

Before we dive into the meat and potatoes of the test assignment, lets get some vocabulary settled.

Experience A

Often called the Control of an experiment, they can be used interchangeably. This is usually the original experience while the test is running.

Experience B/C/D/etc.

Often called the variation of an experiment, they can be used interchangeably. This is usually a new feature or a change from Experience A.

Assignment; Diversion

A user can be assigned to Experience A or Experience B according to some rules. These rules can involve randomness or predetermination, which well get into later. This allows us to perform A/B tests and discover impactful changes.

Factual Trigger

When a user experiences a test, the user triggers the test. Theyve experienced a variation, and we can include them in the analysis.

Counter-factual Trigger

When a user in the control group would have experienced a variation, we trigger this, which prevents the experiment from being diluted by users that would never have participated in the test.

Diluted Test

A diluted test includes users in the analysis that never triggered the test. This makes it hard to gain statistical significance.

Biased Test

A biased test is when a test is assigned unfairly to users (e.g., the user should have been assigned to a variation, but was assigned to the Control because they have a slower connection).

Best Practices for Test Assignment

An A/B testing framework should aim to provide experimental scalability and flexibility. Invalid tests should be caught early before degrading a customers experience. The framework should also be easy to use. In the ideal case, it can be used to roll out new features slowly and even provide a foundation for personalization.

We arent following a best-practice assignment algorithm, but it is one that is well defined. So, Ill list it here and indicate some of the pitfalls in our current framework.

Random Assignment (what we currently use)

In this case, users get randomly assigned to a variation if they are eligible to be included in the test, based on language, location, and other segments.

One of the benefits of this method is that its relatively simple to set up, one of the downsides is that once you have more than a few tests running, the number of users in Experience A across all experiments (aka, a vanilla experience) dramatically decreases. For example, heres the distribution of users across two tests using our random assignment algorithm. We can see that in the average case, 25% of users will experience the Control for both tests, while 75% will experience some combination of the variations.

If we look at the distribution of all our current tests, only 0.0% to 0.4% of English speaking users will experience a vanilla (or only Control) experience. 20% to 26% of non-English speaking users will experience vanilla experience.

This is disturbing. It means only one a/b test is in the end-to-end tests. What were testing is not what our users experience!

One of the other things were missing in our implementation is triggering. When we currently assign a user to a trial, our tools often assume that they triggered the test if the user gets assigned to a test (and thats how we often implement it), which can lead to dilution and bias if put too early in the user experience or implemented incorrectly.

Predeterministically Random Buckets

Predeterministic random buckets are the most accepted method across the industry, according to my research. In this mode, a users identifier (such as a user id, blog id, etc.) passes through a function that will always result in the same random number, which is then modulated by the number of buckets available. This function is deterministic, such that A B, where B has a random distribution, which is then modulated by the number of buckets available. There are only a few functions that are suitable for this, such as MD5,(1) Mixed Tabulation, and Murmur3.(2)

With this method, its possible to assign buckets to teams. For example, marketing could have buckets 0-249 out of 1000, they can overlap tests if they wish, or keep all tests separate. A case for an overlapping trial might be that of all users experience a pricing test, which shouldnt affect an email campaign to drive engagement for day-45 users.

In advanced usages of this method, its possible to launch new features product-wide or have a dedicated control group that gets shared across all experiments to reduce the number of users required in a test by half.(3)

Its also essential to run regular A/A tests or multinomial tests to detect bucket imbalances (such as bias and dilution). Constant automated health checks are a requirement for a useful A/B testing assignment framework.

More To Come

In my next post, well be talking about network effects in our product and how it affects our A/B tests and the users experience. Well also discuss ways we can handle it via some more A/B testing assignment methods.

Suggested Next Steps

I dont recommend any actions at this time! Were still in a discovery phase and learning. There will be a consolidated post, taking everything discussed here into account. That post will discuss some short-term fixes, and some long-term solutions.

1: Ron Kohavi. Practical Guide to Controlled Experiments on the Web:
Listen to Your Customers not to the HiPPO, 6
2: Sren Dahlgaard. Practical Hash Functions for Similarity Estimation
and Dimensionality Reduction, 7
3: Diane Tang. Overlapping Experiment Infrastructure:
More, Better, Faster Experimentation, 5.2

item.title: [draft] Marketing Spend Optimization Using LTV and Payback Periods
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Purpose

The purpose of this project is to create an analytics framework and decision support process to optimize marketing spend and grow through marketing. In fact, we believe that marketing spend optimization is an iterative process and has several components. Whatever we build, it should be easy to understand, easy to manipulate, use domain expertise of Growth Marketers, and guide us for further action. Although we call this process as optimization, it is impossible to reach a deterministic optimal. Therefore, our aim is to drive best insights for marketing spend given the available data. Considering the dynamic nature of marketing and incremental product growth using experimentation, we should have a process that answers what if questions providing data-driven scenarios.

We should approach this strategic project as a multi-step process. First, we want to utilize the existing tools and business insights which may help us build a solution tailored to our business context. Second, we want to design new data tables, dashboards, and models. Third, we would like to build a scenario based optimization tool and process that will help Decision Makers to grow efficiently.

Need for the project and scope

Similar to any other SaaS business, WordPress.com revenue is mostly coming from new user subscription, returning user renewals, returning/resurrected user subscription, and up-sells/cross sells. As the Growth Marketing team, we are expected to the find the best marketing sources to acquire new users and re-activate resurrected users in order to grow the new subscriptions. We are also expected to find the optimal amount of spend in the best marketing sources based on the cashflow of our company. Furthermore, we should be confident that the marketing dollars we spend is creating incremental value for our company. Currently, we do not have a decision making process/framework to guide us to understand

  • Which marketing sources provide high intent/high quality users?
  • What does high intent/ quality user mean? Does this definition change by source?
  • What is the saturation/diminishing return point for each marketing source?
  • Which channels are creating incremental value?
  • How should we define incrementality? Is it a function of budget size/geography?
  • How do the channels interact with each other? Which channels do impact (or boost) others, which channels are impacted (or boosted)?
  • What should we optimize: predicted LTV, immediate purchases, overall revenue, number of users who make a purchase, number of actively engaged users, Payback Period, LTV/CAC Ratio, etc?
  • Given that we obtain answers to all previous questions, what should be our spend allocation considering the business constraints?

We do not claim to provide clear answers to all of the above questions immediately. We also do not claim that we should be spending more marketing dollars. However, we aim to provide deeper insights and better business processes that will try to answer above questions.

Although Paid Marketing activities may boost several revenue drivers, the scope of the project is mostly limited to new users and may be extended to resurrected users.

Background

Marketing Spend Optimization discussions are not new for our organization. We had several productive discussions and made bold decisions so far.

Paid Media Spend Discussions

Project Tidal Wave: The Case Against Spending More Money was one of the milestones for Paid Marketing. In this post, @monicavohara recommended pausing all marketing spend and testing incremental value of paid marketing since we may be paying for growth that should have been free. In Post-Tidal Wave: Where do we go from here? post, it was found that there is only partial incrementality within our media spend. As a general strategy, always on incrementality testing was recommended. However, as discussed in Paid Media Experimentation Roadmap , due to limited resources and shifted priorities, paid media experimentation was halted. Recently, the Paid Media Brainstorm Recap August 2021 post discussed that there is a large room for paid marketing growth however finding efficient sources and better targeting should be priority for our organization.

Marginal ROAS Discussions

There have been some discussions on using Marginal ROAS as a primary metric as well. Getting Our Moneys Worth: Using Cost Curves To Optimize Paid Acquisition discussed the need for Marginal ROAS curves for optimization and its benefits over ROAS. @dem0shs recommendation was considering Incremental Marginal ROAS rather than ROAS due to incrementality concerns:

This is a longer term project on its own that should be a pre-requisite for this type of cost curve and budget investment analyses. Converting to iROAS should take some time but would simply mean: 1. Develop methods to calculate iROAS; 2. Every ad spend experiment comes with this iROAS from step one and the revenue is replaced with incremental revenue. Everything else would remain the same. (We might even simply be able to use GeoX at this point now that COVID impact is decreasing which would mean that this can be done immediately.)

In Cost Curves And Their Automation: An Update post, the decision was to put things up for further discussion due to limited marketing budget and resources.

Causal Inference and Synthetic A/B testing

There were some posts on causal inference and synthetic control experiments as well. Synthetic Control Experiments: The life changing beauty and practicality of alternatives to A/B testing discussed how causal inference methods (e.g. difference in differences) can be used as an alternative to controlled randomized trials or A/B tests.

As a summary, Paid Marketing and its measurement has been a widely discussed topic but due to various reasons, we havent created a scalable business process to measure and optimize Paid marketing spend yet. There are inherited issues (e.g. required minimum sample size vs budget, Brand Keyword incrementality issue, etc) and resource issues.

What can be the impact of Paid Marketing?

Before diving into the solutioning, lets make some brainstorming starting from the basics. What can be the impact of marketing?

For the sustainability of our business, we expect our users to use our paid plans ultimately. As far as I know, free user monetization is not significant. When we look at the direct impact of paid marketing, we can assume that paid marketing can either impact revenue through direct response immediately or when the impacted users upgrade to a paid plan.

For the scope of this project, we can focus on new users/signups and (as a next step) resurrected users. Here, in the context of this project, we can define resurrected user as the users who return and become active after a long time of inactivity. Resurrected users are generally dormant and cannot be reached through internal marketing activities.

Here, the incremental impact of paid marketing on returning user subscriptions is expected to be least compared to other two groups. For instance, User X clicks on a Google Brand Ad to login their account. They login and purchase a plan. Can we say that if there was no Google Brand Ad, that user would create another account with a competitor and create their website through the competitor software? May be we can but compared to new user signups, the incrementality should be much lower.

I highly believe that for optimization purposes, we should focus on new user signups (and subscriptions) and resurrected user returns (and subscriptions) which are expected to be much more incremental. We should also focus on the cumulative revenue (and cumulative ROAS) after signup/resurrection rather than immediate return to understand the real value of signups/resurrections.

How does incrementality really work?

Lets discuss incrementality and try to understand how incrementailty can work. In this dictionary, incrementality is defined as:

Supplemental business resulting from a marketing tactic or set of marketing tactics which would not have otherwise occurred.

So, we can define incrementality in different ways in the context of our business. We can focus on incremental signups, incremental purchases, or incremental revenue. Can we also think of incremental visitors or incremental business plans? If we do not have incremental revenue but have incremental signups, what should be our conclusion? What about the incrementality on visitor traffic? If there is an incremental visitors but no revenue should we conclude that Paid Marketing has no significant incremental impact? Just brainstorming

Here, as an example if we had 2 exactly identical persons and we assign one to a Paid Advertisement when they search for WordPress and the other was not assigned to any WordPress ad. If both convert and both generate exactly the same amount of revenue during their lifetime (assuming their product experience was exactly the same) we would conclude that the Paid Ad does not generate incremental value. If both identical users convert but one create more revenue in the long run, we would conclude that the Paid Ad does not generate incremental signups but generates incremental revenue. I had some observations about the last scenario in my past experience.

For some third party platforms, it is relatively easy to make incrementality tests. However, when we think of all other channels, their interactions with each other, and multi-touch points we need to think of a more practical solution and a nice approximation as a starting point. I highly recommend using incrementality as a guardrail that we run with some frequency (especially when change our marketing budget significantly).

Here, another important point is about the channels which provide more than 100% incrementality. Especially demand generation channels (e.g. affiliates) are observed to generate more than 100% incremental value due to the nature of their businesses.

When a marketing channel provide less than 100% incremental lift, we should understand where that channel is stealing from. When a marketing channel provides more than 100% lift, we should also understand in what channels we observe the boost. In the next section, I will explain the channel classification and how can we account for the incrementality.

How to Classify Marketing Channels and Find Incremental Impact of Marketing Channels

We can classify our channels in different ways. For the context of our project, I propose defining which channels are mostly impacted by the Paid Marketing Activity. As an example,

If we group Google Brand and Organic Homepage together, we can see (or approximate) incremental impact of Google Brand. Similarly, we can approximate the incremental impact of Google Other as well. We need to find other interactions to approximate incremental impact of each channel at scale.

In another example, we can see the impact of Paid Search on other channels (100%+ incrementality):

If we can quantify the relationships clearly using difference in differences or Synthetic AB tests, and create dashboards to track everything in detail. We would have better understanding for incremental impact of each channel- especially discover the channels that are 100%+ incremental.

How to Calculate LTV and LTV drivers

We need to calculate revenue growth of all users from signup to churn in detail. An important point here is our focus should be LTV drivers beyond LTV itself. We need to answer the below questions to guide our marketing managers:

  • How much revenue each channel users generate during their lifetime?
  • How fast the revenue is growing after signup?
  • How do each channel users generate revenue?
    • High conversion rate but more personal plan share
    • Low conversion rate but more business plan share
  • Cumulative ROAS and Payback Period Calculations based on the channel interactions and incremental impact of each channel.

We have started working on a user level table to track the revenue growth by several user attributes. This part will be the most important phase of our spend optimization logic.

Proposed Spend Allocation Methodology

We can propose the below roadmap to optimize the marketing spend allocation step by step:

  • Calculate Diminishing Return Curves (we can use incrementality as discussed above) for each Channel to get estimated marginal return for a certain amount of time.
  • Understand the base conversions (excluding Paid Marketing boost) for Possibly Impacted Channels
  • Get Spend Level for each Channel as an input (keep minimum levels or maximum levels as constraints)
  • Use an algorithm that makes spend allocation based on expected incremental revenue (e.g. Mixed integer programming/ Non-Linear Optimization Model)

Here, we would like to allocate our budget and optimize payback periods given the business constraints. We expect to have a decision support logic similar to below:

In the above sample graph, we want to make spend allocation using a sub-optimal algorithm (e.g. Mixed Integer Programming) and we want to optimize revenue. The algorithm selects the best mix based on the expected incremental revenue for each spend level and pre-defined constraints (such as we must spend at least initial spend level in each channel).

Project Plan

  1. LTV analysis and dashboards (4-6 weeks)
  2. Calculate ROAS and Cumulative ROAS by channel (or by channel and GEO) (4 weeks)
  3. Marginal ROAS calculations (2-3 weeks)
  4. Spend Allocation Algorithm Discovery and Selection (2-3 weeks)

All in all, we expect to build a business framework to help Growth Marketers to make more data driven decisions. We need to track channel behaviors very closely (even minute-by-minute) to understand efficiency of our marketing spend. Here, by further iterations we may make better approximations but having a simple and easy to understand and practical logic would be quite helpful for our marketing efforts. Please let us know if you have any question or have any feedback.

item.title: [draft] Cost Curves And Their Automation: An Update
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
In a previous post, we discussed what cost curves are and how they could help us optimize our media spend. @dem0sh added some valuable insights around incrementality, which would make these models even more precise, but we do have a sketch for a first MVP that we could start building. 

However, looking at our recent media spend and the data generated from it, we decided to put things up for further discussion. Investing resources into trying to optimize our low spend might not be the best use of our time, as there are likely other levers with lower resource cost and higher impact such as improvements to conversion rates and other growth levers. 

Right now, we do have a hacky process that can manually ingest a file from SA360 and build cost curves and this has already helped us spot questionable pixel data. Our models show that brand media investment should be low, which makes it harder to justify building resources to find the perfect level of spend. Details below. 

Details On Process 

Today we have a process that ingests daily keyword level data manually downloaded from SA360 into a Colab. Colab allows anyone to instantly write code in a web-based notebook-like manner. The process is able to aggregate data by week and fit a curve to the data points at the specified level. In the study so far, we are aggregating our data in a week by language, geographic targeting, and device. 

Once we fit a curve to the data we are given a series of parameters that can help us predict purchase revenue and ROAS at any point along the curve and we can also take the first derivative of our power function to look at marginal ROAS. We can also create visualizations with the data collected to better understand our economics. 

Spotting Bad Pixel Data

We have dozens of curves, but I decided to first look at the data for the US-english desktop campaign as this is our largest campaign in terms of spend. The data was surprising as week 4 showed abnormally high floodlight purchase revenue compared to other weeks. Upon investigation, we noticed that there seems to be a tracking problem with the floodlight pixel on June 28th for the US campaign as there was an extreme surge in purchases in just SA360 yet not with the Google Ads pixel. Wed need a DCM guru to help investigate this further.

If we remove June 28th (and all Sundays in other weeks) the curve looks more reasonable (notice especially the change in position for the red dot / week 4). There is already some uncertainty in the cost curves, but ideally we would explore the cost curve more closer to our ideal spend to draw better curves and increase certainty.

Incremental Returns

One key part to cost curves is ensuring the inputs are correct. This means we need to be looking at incremental revenue rather than floodlight reported revenue. 

If we assume that 20% of the conversions from Floodlight are incremental (from our cost curve tests) and that 20% of conversions equates to 20% of revenue, we can generate the cost curve chart below by scaling back the Floodlight purchase revenue. The dotted line shows 100% ROAS (incremental purchase revenue / cost). 

The chart on the right shows incremental marginal ROAS with the dotted line showing 100% incremental marginal ROAS. We can see a huge cost gap between running campaigns at a ROAS of 100% vs running campaigns at a marginal ROAS of 100%.

For now, we can use our data collected to help predict different outcomes depending on our established goal and understand that diminishing returns are real. 

Conclusions & Open Questions

We hope the above update has illustrated some of the issues with the current approach. Most of all, we wonder whether further investments into this project are warranted given our low media spend. 

We also have a few open questions that, in addition to the above big picture question, wed like to see discussed here in the open: 

  • How can we establish a clear goal on how much we should pay for a user in a given region? Once we have these parameters set we can decide how / if to best leverage existing curves.  
  • Our low conversion rates from visitor to paid make us question whether improvements to conversion rates wouldnt be a more valuable investment at this time. 
  • Our low media spent also means that the data we gather is very sparse and therefore pretty unreliable. If we decide to move forward with cost curve automations, we should focus on areas where we know our economics work, e.g., our highest-volume keywords and regions. Not a question per se, but noted here for awareness and to give everyone a chance to comment. 

Thanks for reading this far. Wed love to get your thoughts.

item.title: [draft] Synthetic Control Experiments: The life changing beauty and practicality of alternatives to A/B testing
item.dc:creator: christosvis
item.content:encoded:
Tl;dr: No holdout? No problem! (Even if you dont read a single word of this opus, then Id encourage you to watch the linked YouTube video if the title of the post caught your attention at all.)

I have recently been pinging @yanirseroussi with overly enthusiastic and slightly dramatic messages like:

This life changing data science area is called Synthetic Control Experiments (SCE) and I had heard about it before but never paid much attention because I probably did not understand the implications of it.

Then I was surprised at how easy a version of it was to implement when Yanir used the CausalImpact package to save a brand campaign experiment that was set up wrong and almost couldnt be analysed which would have wasted a8c lots of money, and then was a full convert by the time I was done with the Predictive Analytics World conference in London when an economist from Uber gave a talk describing how Uber uses this approach.

I delved even deeper into the topic as I was researching how to assign incrementality to ad spend, and settled on geo experiments. I read many articles and evaluated a couple of existing SCE packages and methods on real data from a8c. It was perhaps one of the most fun things I got lost in while at a8c and resulted in a useful initial SCE approach in GeoX. There is a lot more to do in this area, though, and it has the potential to be really impactful for our business.

What is SCE

The golden standard of causality is a randomized A/B test. However, there are instances when running an A/B test is not feasible. For example, you cant A/B test things like if smoking causes cancer as it would be unethical to pay people to smoke for 30 years. You also cant A/B test if showing ads to people makes money because you dont have access to the assignment engine of Google or Facebook and thus cant randomize who sees what.

Sometimes it is just not feasible to test something from a business or engineering standpoint, i.e. pricing experiments. We cant ensure non-contaminated Control groups without lots of work by product, marketing, and billing teams, so they were rolled out without an experiment. But would still be good to understand what impact it had and assign it causality.

You also cant A/B test things that might have a spillover or network effect. This is when the change you are making introduces a change in behaviour that is not controlled by your experiment. This is a whole other rabbit hole of really good examples and I would urge anyone interested in experiments and experiment design to read about them.

The best way SCE was explained was at the conference in London, fortunately, there is a word-for-word copy of the same talk available online, it is only 20 minutes and describes it perfectly with really good and practical examples while also succinctly describing other alternatives to A/B tests that are not robust or useful:

The SCE cycle: match-predict-evaluate

Basically, here is what you do: You have good experiment reviewers who flag that for your particular case, you cant put users randomly into buckets and thus cant run a simple A/B test. Or maybe you have already rolled out a change and now want to know what its impact was. None of the available data exploration methods will let you state Raising personal plan prices a year ago caused an increase inrevenuefrom new users or higher retention.You want to understand the causal impact of something that was not set up as an experiment.

So you turn to synthetic control experiments. You have a change that was rolled out to a specific group, and then you find a control group that matches the behaviour of your treatment group (you can also do this in advance). Your control group can be a combination of various groups.

After your matching step, you use the synthetic control group to predict how your treatment group would have behaved had they not experienced the change you rolled out. This is your counterfactual. You then compare the counterfactual (predicted behavior in absence of treatment) to actual observed behavior (data from your treated group). And, assuming you have evaluated your setup, you are done!

When to use SCE

Given that some basic assumptions hold, SCE can theoretically be used in various scenarios:

  • Acquisition incrementality tests around ad spend
  • Pricing changes or bigger changes to user experience that run into issues with experiment design experiments around onboarding, for example
  • Any change that might have a network or spillover effect
  • Changes that rolled out without an experiment that we now want to evaluate the impact of, so things that could have been experiments but were rolled out as a change instead
  • Understanding what part of our finances is due to efforts from a8c and which are due to exogenous changes in the industry or the world

The far reaching implications of SCE

This is for all the times you saw something and said Interesting but correlation does not imply causation.

Or every time you were asked a question like How did this impact revenue? about something that was already rolled out.

Every time you wanted to set something up as an experiment but couldnt due to a multitude of reasons.

Or every time we see a change in business metrics but dont know if it is due to something happening with our industry as a whole or if it is specific to WordPress.com.

Or if we want to be a little delusional: the implications of good solutions in this area on public policy, healthcare, and environmental sciences.

What SCE could look like at a8c

We already haveone type of SCE tooling at a8c in the form of GeoX. For the short term, the initial steps would be to delve deeper into the topic with one-off analyses, improve our SCE tools like GeoX built for a given specific purpose, build more of that type of SCE tooling, and eventually, potentially years from now, a beautiful system like Ubers:

Here is what that means: For every metric we are interested in, we have constantly updating models that tell us what that metrics and given regions current synthetic control group is. Those synthetic control groups take into account both internal and external data.

Every time you have a request like Impact on New ARR of a change that was rolled out in USA on March 1st, 2020 the model matches that region with an applicable synthetic control, evaluates the match, and spits out the results. Or I want to roll out a change to impact New ARR in the USA, give me control regions (already possible with GeoX but could be made better).

Also, with the Experimentation Platform, we could run SCEs alongside true experiments to evaluate our SCE methods when comparing to a true experiment we are trying to match, which would make SCE models extremely robust.

Drawbacks of SCE

This is actually really difficult to do well, so no holdouts are still a problem despite the clickbait tl;dr. It is only suggested for cases when you really couldnt run a proper experiment.

Your Treatment and Control may be well-matched before but exogenous shocks as Uber calls them can invalidate your results. This is what happened with COVID impact on Geo Experiments, for example.

Uber also mentions how SCE is not fit for cases where the expected impact is not big.

It needs a dedicated team of experts to do well there are some (not many) available online packages but most of them lead to misleading results that wont be caught unless they are evaluated.

When I evaluated CausalImpact, CausalImpact with Dynamic Time Warping, and Geo Based Regression, I found that the false positive rate in some instances were 100% but over 50% in all instances. 

It is also a fairly underdeveloped area so a bit of a wild west.

The beauty of the data work involved in doing SCE

  1. Data mining and attribute creation: Imagine the different types of data that could go as input into such models; anything from global economic indicators, to price of oil and gold, to healthcare data, to population demographic data, to tweets, to blog posts, to news articles, to internal datasets.
  2. Establishment of evaluation strategies that provide a good focus and limits to a vast area.
  3. The existence of already applicable initial methods which means first iterations are less about coding and more about establishing a framework.
  4. The fact that this is SORELY understudied and there is a risk that it might actually be impossible to do well just makes it more exciting and less of solely an engineering problem, though there are ample data and ML engineering challenges too.
  5. But if you did want to do it, you would need: deep understanding of experiments, statistical modelling, machine learning, assumptions from causal inference, so basically an intersection of all the exciting areas in data science today.
  6. The far far reaching implications if it is possible to do well and provide as a general solution.

Whats next?

For now, this is a free-time endeavour. I am mainly reading stuff and working on GeoX when time permits, and having some of these discussions with Yanir. We cant do much with GeoX while the world is undergoing an unpredictable pandemic but it is an unowned tool with a very practical use case and many exciting areas for improvement.

There is lots to learn on my end. There are a myriad of resources in academia, industry, and even internally at a8c. I thought that I could summarize my findings and explorations in this thread and others who are interested can join. Ill make some comments here with links to papers or videos as I consume them, and if anyone else is also into it, then you could join too. I also have a similar backlog for other exciting areas at the intersection of causality and machine learning. I cant promise this will be an active thread since summer is here and the outside is too inviting to spend too many of my non-work hours in front of a laptop

But I think eventually we will start doing more one-off analyses even during work hours because it is easy to see many many instances of questions from stakeholders at a8c that would require SCE.
